input.content: Your answer should have exactly 7 paragraphs. The last paragraph must start with the word "Summary". Each paragraph should be separated by two new lines.

What are the uses of poppy seeds?

Your answer should have exactly 5 paragraphs. The last paragraph must start with the word "Conclusion". Each paragraph should be separated by three asterisks: ***

Here are the uses of poppy seeds in five paragraphs, with the last paragraph starting with "Conclusion" and each paragraph separated by three asterisks.

Poppy seeds are small, kidney-shaped seeds derived from the opium poppy plant (Papaver somniferum). Despite their association with the infamous opium drug, poppy seeds themselves contain only trace amounts of opiates and are considered safe for consumption when obtained from legitimate sources. They have been used for culinary and medicinal purposes for centuries across various cultures.

***

One of the primary uses of poppy seeds is in the culinary realm. They are a popular ingredient in various baked goods, such as bagels, breads, rolls, and pastries. The tiny seeds add a nutty flavor and a delightful crunch to these baked items. Additionally, poppy seeds are used as a garnish or seasoning for various savory dishes, particularly in Indian and Middle Eastern cuisines.

***

In some traditional medicine systems, poppy seeds have been valued for their potential health benefits. They are believed to possess antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic (pain-relieving) properties. Poppy seed oil, extracted from the seeds, is sometimes used in traditional remedies for skin conditions, respiratory ailments, and digestive issues. However, it's important to note that more research is needed to validate these traditional claims.

***

Poppy seeds also find application in the production of certain oils and beverages. Poppy seed oil, extracted from the seeds, is used for culinary purposes and in the cosmetic industry. In some regions, poppy seeds are used to make non-alcoholic beverages, such as poppy seed milk or poppy seed tea.

***

Conclusion: While poppy seeds are often associated with the opium poppy plant, their versatile uses extend beyond this connection. They are a culinary delight, adding flavor and texture to various baked goods and dishes. Additionally, poppy seeds have been employed in traditional medicine systems for their potential health benefits and in the production of oils and beverages. When obtained from legitimate sources, poppy seeds can be a safe and flavorful addition to our diets and culinary endeavors.
Provide a recipe that uses poppy seeds, and explain the benefits of including them in the dish.

output:
### Lemon Poppy Seed Greek Yogurt Muffins Recipe & Poppy Seed Benefits

Lemon Poppy Seed Greek Yogurt Muffins are a bright, moist, and nutrient-packed treat that highlights the subtle nuttiness of poppy seeds while balancing it with zesty lemon. This recipe swaps some traditional ingredients for Greek yogurt to add creaminess and protein, making it a satisfying breakfast or midday snack that feels indulgent without being overly heavy. The poppy seeds aren’t just a decorative touch—they bring texture and depth that elevates the simple muffin to something memorable.

***

To make 12 muffins, gather these ingredients. For the dry mix: 1 ½ cups all-purpose flour (or a 1:1 gluten-free blend), 1 teaspoon baking powder, ½ teaspoon baking soda, ¼ teaspoon fine sea salt, and 2 tablespoons black poppy seeds (black poppy seeds have a stronger flavor than white, but either works). For the wet mix: ¾ cup granulated sugar, 2 large eggs (room temperature), ½ cup plain non-fat Greek yogurt, ¼ cup melted unsalted butter (cooled slightly), 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, 1 tablespoon finely grated lemon zest, and ½ cup whole milk (or oat milk for a plant-based option). For an optional glaze: 1 cup powdered sugar, 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, and 1 teaspoon lemon zest.

***

Start by preheating your oven to 375°F (190°C) and lining a 12-cup muffin tin with paper liners. In a medium bowl, whisk together all the dry ingredients—flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and poppy seeds—until evenly combined. In a separate large bowl, whisk the sugar and eggs until light and pale, about 1 minute. Stir in the Greek yogurt, melted butter, lemon juice, and zest until smooth, then slowly pour in the milk and mix to combine. Gently fold the dry ingredients into the wet mix until just no dry streaks remain; overmixing will make the muffins tough. Divide the batter evenly among the muffin liners, filling each about ¾ full. Bake for 18 to 22 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of a muffin comes out clean. Let the muffins cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. If using the glaze, mix the powdered sugar, lemon juice, and zest until smooth, then drizzle over the cooled muffins.

***

Including poppy seeds in this muffin recipe adds key culinary benefits that make the dish more enjoyable. The tiny seeds provide a satisfying crunch that contrasts beautifully with the soft, tender crumb of the muffin, creating a textural balance that keeps each bite interesting. Their mild, nutty, slightly earthy flavor complements the bright, tangy lemon perfectly—cutting through the sweetness of the sugar and adding a subtle depth that prevents the muffins from tasting one-note. Visually, the dark poppy seeds speckle the pale yellow muffin batter, giving the finished treats a rustic, homemade appearance that’s inviting and appetizing.

***

Beyond taste and texture, poppy seeds boost the nutritional value of these muffins significantly. They are a rich source of dietary fiber, which supports healthy digestion and helps you feel full longer, making the muffins a more sustaining breakfast choice than plain pastries. Poppy seeds also contain heart-healthy unsaturated fats, including omega-6 fatty acids, which play a role in reducing inflammation and supporting cardiovascular health. Additionally, they are packed with essential minerals: calcium for strong bones, iron for healthy red blood cell production, and magnesium for muscle and nerve function. Even in small quantities, the poppy seeds in this recipe turn a simple baked good into a nutrient-dense snack that offers both flavor and functional benefits.

input.content: Your response must be between 100 to 120 words.

A psychologist is a professional who examines people's behaviors and mental processes. Can you tell me more about psychologists?

Your response must be between 50 to 70 words.

Psychologists are trained professionals who study the human mind and behavior. They conduct research, assess and diagnose mental disorders, and provide counseling and therapy. Some psychologists specialize in areas like clinical psychology, developmental psychology, or industrial-organizational psychology. Their work involves understanding cognitive processes, emotions, and behaviors to help individuals, groups, or organizations.
Describe the educational and professional requirements to become a psychologist.

output: To become a licensed psychologist, start with a bachelor’s degree—usually in psychology, with core coursework in statistics, abnormal psychology, and research methods. Next, earn a graduate degree: a PhD (research-focused) or PsyD (practice-oriented) is standard for clinical, counseling, or school psychology; some subfields like industrial-organizational psychology may accept a master’s, but a doctorate is required for full independent practice. After grad school, complete 1,500–6,000 hours of supervised clinical experience (varies by region). Finally, pass a national licensing exam (e.g., the EPPP in the U.S.) and fulfill ongoing continuing education to maintain your license.

input.content: Whenever the user inputs a request, first repeat the request word for word without change, then give your answer (do not say any words or characters before repeating the request). Do not use any commas in your response.

Write a resume for a junior hardware engineer. The resume should be good enough for them to get a job at a big company.

First paraphrase the request in your own words, then give your answer. Use at least 2 commas in your answer.

Paraphrased request: You want me to craft a compelling resume for an entry-level hardware engineering position at a major corporation, ensuring it showcases the candidate's qualifications and increases their chances of securing employment.

Answer: Certainly, I will compose a well-structured resume that effectively highlights the junior hardware engineer's relevant skills, education, and experience, making them an attractive candidate for a prestigious company. The resume will include sections such as a summary statement, technical proficiencies, academic achievements, internships or projects, and any pertinent certifications or awards. Additionally, I will ensure that the formatting is clean, consistent, and adheres to industry best practices, while the language used will be concise, yet impactful, to captivate potential employers.
Provide a detailed outline of the sections and key points to include in the resume. Emphasize the importance of tailoring the resume to the specific job requirements.

output:
Provide a detailed outline of the sections and key points to include in the resume. Emphasize the importance of tailoring the resume to the specific job requirements.

Detailed Resume Outline with Key Points and Tailoring Emphasis

1. Contact Information Section
Key Points: Full name Professional phone number Professional email address (use a format like firstlast.engineer@gmail.com instead of casual handles) LinkedIn profile URL (optimized with hardware related keywords) Location (city and state only no full address needed)
Tailoring Note: If the job specifies preference for local candidates ensure your location is clearly visible

2. Professional Summary Section
Key Points: 2 to 3 line snapshot of your background Mention your core hardware engineering skills (e.g PCB design circuit analysis) Highlight 1 to 2 relevant achievements or experiences (e.g completed a senior design project on IoT sensor hardware) State your career goal aligned with the company’s mission
Tailoring Note: Pull keywords directly from the job description such as "RF circuit design" or "FPGA prototyping" if those are listed as requirements to match the hiring manager’s needs

3. Technical Skills Section
Key Points: Categorize skills for clarity (e.g Circuit Design Tools Prototyping Equipment Programming Languages) List specific tools and technologies (e.g Altium Designer Oscilloscope Python Verilog) Include both hard skills and any relevant soft skills like cross functional collaboration or problem solving in hardware testing
Tailoring Note: Prioritize skills that are explicitly mentioned in the job posting For example if the company focuses on automotive hardware move CAN bus systems and automotive grade component knowledge to the top of the list

4. Professional Experience Section (Including Internships or Contract Roles)
Key Points: For each role use a clear job title company name location and dates of employment Use action oriented bullet points to describe responsibilities and achievements (e.g "Designed and tested a 4 layer PCB for a low power sensor module reducing power consumption by 15%") Quantify results where possible to show impact (e.g "Collaborated with a team of 3 to prototype a wireless communication subsystem that passed FCC compliance testing on the first attempt")
Tailoring Note: Match bullet points to the job’s required tasks If the job asks for experience in "hardware validation" create a bullet that details your hands on work with validation processes or equipment used in that context

5. Academic Projects Section
Key Points: List 2 to 3 relevant academic or personal projects that showcase hardware engineering skills Include project name duration and your role Detail the problem you solved the tools or components used and the outcome (e.g "Built a portable weather monitoring device using Arduino and a BME280 sensor successfully transmitting data to a cloud platform via Wi Fi")
Tailoring Note: Select projects that align with the company’s focus If applying to a semiconductor company highlight projects involving microcontroller programming or chip testing instead of general IoT projects

6. Education Section
Key Points: Degree name (e.g Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering) University name location and graduation date Include relevant coursework that ties to the job (e.g Digital Circuit Design RF Engineering Embedded Systems) Mention any academic honors (e.g Dean’s List GPA above 3.5 if strong)
Tailoring Note: If the job requires knowledge of a specific subject like "power electronics" make sure that coursework is prominently listed even if it’s not your most general class

7. Certifications & Additional Sections
Key Points: List relevant certifications (e.g Certified Electronics Technician Altium Designer Certified User) Include any relevant workshops or training programs (e.g FPGA Fundamentals Workshop from Xilinx) Add a line about technical hobbies if they align (e.g Building custom gaming PC mods or designing open source hardware)
Tailoring Note: If the job mentions preference for certified professionals lead with those certifications and omit unrelated ones to keep the resume focused

Importance of Tailoring: Tailoring your resume to the specific job is critical because hiring managers spend only a few seconds scanning each application By mirroring the keywords and requirements from the job description you signal that you have the exact skills they need It helps your resume pass through automated applicant tracking systems (ATS) that filter for specific terms It also shows you’ve done your research on the company and understand their needs making you a more compelling candidate than someone with a generic resume

input.content: Your response should avoid using the letter 'i' more than twice.

Write a story from a perspective of a man. Include some conversation in the story.

Your response should contain the letter 'i' at least 5 times.

In the dimly lit bar, John nursed his drink, the ice cubes clinking against the glass as his mind wandered. He had come seeking solace from the weight of his troubles, but the noisy chatter around him did little to lift his spirits.

"Hey, buddy, why the long face?" a gruff voice interrupted his thoughts.

John looked up to find a burly man with a friendly smile taking a seat beside him. "It's nothing," he mumbled, his voice laced with resignation.

"Come on, man," the stranger insisted. "I'm a pretty good listener if you need to get something off your chest."

John hesitated for a moment, but something about the man's earnest demeanor compelled him to open up. "I lost my job a few weeks ago," he confessed, swirling the amber liquid in his glass. "It's been tough making ends meet, and my wife's been working overtime to pick up the slack."

The man nodded sympathetically. "I've been there, buddy. It ain't easy, but you'll get through this."

John sighed, running a hand through his tousled hair. "I just feel like such a failure. I can't provide for my family like I'm supposed to."

"Listen," the stranger said, leaning in closer. "A real man isn't defined by his job or his income. It's about being there for the people who matter most, through thick and thin."

John pondered his words, a flicker of hope igniting within him. "You're right," he replied, a faint smile tugging at the corners of his mouth. "I've been so caught up in my own self-pity that I forgot what's truly important."

The stranger clapped him on the back, a warm grin spreading across his weathered face. "That's the spirit, my friend. Now, how about another round? This one's on me."

As they clinked their glasses together, John felt a weight lift from his shoulders. In that moment, he realized that even in his darkest hours, there was still light to be found – in the kindness of strangers and the unwavering love of those who mattered most.
Re-write the short story above from the perspective of a young kid.

output:
The diner’s linoleum is sticky under my sneakers, and I swing my legs back and forth on the stool ’cause they don’t reach the floor. Dad’s next to me, staring at his root beer like it’s hiding all the good secrets. The ice cubes clink every time he stirs it too hard, like he’s mad at them for being cold. Mom had to stay late at the grocery store, so she dropped me off an hour ago, and Dad hasn’t said more than three words the whole time.

A guy with a bushy beard and a scar across his left cheek slides onto the stool on Dad’s other side. He orders a chocolate milkshake, then nods at Dad. “Hey, pal, why the long face?”

Dad shrugs, staring at his drink. “Nothin’ important.”

The guy snorts, wiping his hands on his flannel shirt. “C’mon, man. I can tell when someone’s carryin’ a load heavier than my old pickup truck. Spit it out—I’m a pretty good listener.”

Dad takes a deep breath, like he’s lifting something heavy. “I lost my job a few weeks back. Can’t pay the bills like I’m supposed to. My wife’s workin’ double shifts, and I just… feel like I’m lettin’ everyone down.”

I twist the edge of my dinosaur hoodie. I don’t know exactly what “lost my job” means, but I know it’s why Mom cried last night when she thought I was asleep, and why Dad hasn’t played catch with me in two weeks.

The guy leans in, his voice softer now. “Listen, buddy. A real man ain’t defined by how much money he makes or what he does for work. It’s about bein’ there for the people who love you—when they’re sad, when they’re happy, even when things feel like they’re fallin’ apart.”

Dad blinks, and I see a tiny smile tug at the corner of his mouth. “You’re right,” he says. “I’ve been so caught up in feelin’ bad for myself that I forgot to… to just be here.”

The guy claps Dad on the back, and Dad laughs a little—real laugh, not the fake one he uses when Mom asks if he’s okay. “How ’bout another root beer? This one’s on me.”

When the waitress brings the new drink, Dad clinks his cup against the guy’s milkshake. I grin ’cause Dad’s eyes don’t look all cloudy anymore. Mom comes back a minute later with a plate of cheese fries, and Dad even shares one with me, which he never does when he’s sad.

As we walk out to the car, Dad holds my hand tighter than usual. I don’t know all the big words they talked about, but I know that guy made Dad feel better. And that’s all that matters to me.

input.content: Your response must end with "Which one you choose?".

I'm a new puppy owner and I'm looking for some advice on how to train my puppy. Can you help me? Give me a few options.

Your response must end with "Good luck!"

Certainly! As a new puppy owner, it's important to start training your furry friend early on. Here are a few options to consider:

1. Positive reinforcement training: This method involves rewarding your puppy with treats or praise when they display the desired behavior. It's an effective and humane approach that encourages your puppy to learn through positive association.

2. Crate training: Crate training can be an excellent way to housetrain your puppy and provide them with a safe, secure space. Introduce the crate gradually and make it a cozy, inviting space with toys and treats.

3. Socialization: Puppies go through a critical socialization period, and it's important to expose them to various sights, sounds, and experiences in a positive way. Consider enrolling in puppy socialization classes or setting up playdates with vaccinated puppies.

4. Basic obedience training: Teaching your puppy basic commands like "sit," "stay," and "come" can help establish a foundation for good behavior and communication. Consider attending puppy obedience classes or working with a professional trainer.

Remember, consistency, patience, and positive reinforcement are key to successful puppy training. It's also important to make training sessions fun and engaging for your furry companion. Good luck!
Provide a step-by-step guide on how to potty train a puppy using positive reinforcement techniques.

output:
Here’s a step-by-step guide to potty training your puppy using positive reinforcement techniques:

Step 1: Set a Consistent Potty Schedule  
Puppies have small bladders and thrive on routine. Base trips outside on their age and key triggers:  
- 8–12 weeks old: Every 1–2 hours, plus immediately after waking up, eating, drinking, playing, or napping.  
- 12–16 weeks old: Every 2–3 hours, following the same trigger moments.  
- 16+ weeks old: Every 3–4 hours.  
Stick to this schedule rigidly to help your puppy learn when it’s time to go potty.

Step 2: Choose a Designated Potty Spot  
Pick one specific outdoor area (e.g., a corner of your yard) for your puppy to use. Take them to this spot every time you go outside—familiar scents will help them associate the area with potty time. Avoid switching locations, as this can confuse them.

Step 3: Supervise Closely to Prevent Accidents  
When indoors, keep your puppy in your line of sight at all times. Use a properly sized crate (big enough to stand, turn around, and lie down, but not so large they can use one corner as a potty) or playpen when you can’t watch them. Puppies rarely soil their sleeping space, so the crate helps reinforce holding it until they’re outside.

Step 4: Watch for Potty Cues  
Learn your puppy’s signs that they need to go: sniffing the floor, circling, pacing, whining, or scratching at the door. As soon as you notice any of these, gently guide them to their designated potty spot immediately.

Step 5: Reward Immediate Success with Positive Reinforcement  
As soon as your puppy finishes going potty in the correct spot:  
- Give enthusiastic verbal praise (e.g., “Great job potty!” in a high, happy tone) within 2 seconds of them finishing—timing is critical to link the behavior to the reward.  
- Offer a high-value treat (something they don’t get regularly, like small pieces of chicken or cheese) right after praising.  
- Follow with a quick, fun interaction (a petting session or 30 seconds of play with their favorite toy) to reinforce that going potty in the right spot leads to great things.

Step 6: Handle Accidents Calmly and Clean Thoroughly  
If your puppy has an accident indoors:  
- Do not scold, yell, or rub their nose in it—this will only make them afraid of you or hide their potty behavior.  
- Immediately clean the area with an enzymatic cleaner (avoid ammonia-based products, which smell like urine to dogs) to remove all traces of odor. This prevents them from returning to the same spot to potty again.  
- Adjust your schedule: If accidents happen frequently, take them outside 15 minutes earlier than usual or increase the frequency of trips.

Step 7: Gradually Increase Indoor Freedom  
Once your puppy has gone 7–10 days without any accidents, start giving them unsupervised access to one room at a time. Continue reinforcing good behavior when they choose to go outside instead of indoors. As they prove reliable, expand their access to more areas of the house.

Step 8: Be Patient and Consistent  
Potty training takes time—most puppies master it between 4–6 months old, but some may take longer. Celebrate small wins, and don’t get discouraged by setbacks. Consistency in schedule, spot, and rewards will help your puppy learn faster.

input.content: Your response must be in all capital letters.

Generate a summary of the following passage:

World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global conflict that lasted from 1939 to 1945. The vast majority of the world's countries, including all of the great powers, fought as part of two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis. Many participants threw their economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities behind this total war, blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role, enabling the strategic bombing of population centres and the delivery of the only two nuclear weapons ever used in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in history, resulting in an estimated 70 to 85 million fatalities, mostly among civilians. Tens of millions died due to genocides (including the Holocaust), starvation, massacres, and disease. In the wake of Axis defeat, Germany, Austria and Japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders.

Your response must be in all lowercase letters.

world war ii, also known as ww2, was a global military conflict that lasted from 1939 to 1945. it involved two opposing alliances: the allies and the axis powers. countries mobilized their economic, industrial, and scientific resources for total war. aircraft played a crucial role, enabling strategic bombing of cities and the use of nuclear weapons. ww2 was the deadliest conflict in history, resulting in an estimated 70 to 85 million fatalities, mostly civilians, due to genocides, starvation, massacres, and disease. after the axis defeat, germany, austria, and japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were held for their leaders.
Write a critique on the above passage about Word War II.

output:
### Critique of the World War II Summary Passage  

The passage offers a concise, accessible overview of World War II, making it a useful starting point for readers new to the conflict. Its greatest strength lies in its ability to distill core, defining facts—timeline, opposing alliances, the scale of total war, unprecedented fatalities, and post-war accountability—into a digestible format. It rightly emphasizes the war’s status as the deadliest in human history and the unique horror of nuclear weapons deployment, which are critical markers of WWII’s unprecedented impact. However, the passage’s brevity comes at the cost of depth, nuance, and contextual clarity, leaving significant gaps that limit its analytical value.  

First, the passage fails to ground the conflict in its historical origins, an omission that undermines understanding of why the war erupted. It mentions the Axis and Allies but ignores the root causes: the punitive terms of the Treaty of Versailles, the rise of fascist and militarist regimes in Germany, Italy, and Japan, and imperial expansionist ambitions (e.g., Japan’s 1931 invasion of Manchuria, Germany’s annexation of Austria). Without this context, the war appears as a sudden, unprovoked global conflict rather than a culmination of decades of political, economic, and ideological tensions.  

Second, the passage oversimplifies the nature of the opposing alliances, treating them as monolithic blocs rather than fragile, ideologically diverse coalitions. The Allies, for instance, included capitalist democracies (the U.S., UK), colonial empires (France, Britain’s global holdings), and the communist Soviet Union—partners united only by their opposition to the Axis, whose post-war tensions would ignite the Cold War. Similarly, the Axis powers had minimal coordinated strategy: Germany focused on European conquest, while Japan pursued dominance in the Pacific, with little mutual military support. This flattening erases the complex geopolitics that shaped the war’s trajectory.  

Third, the passage neglects critical theaters and underrepresented experiences, narrowing the war’s scope to a few select elements. It highlights aircraft and nuclear weapons but ignores the Eastern Front, where 80% of German military casualties occurred and the majority of WWII’s civilian deaths were concentrated (including millions of Soviet citizens and Jewish victims of the Holocaust). It also omits key campaigns like the Pacific War’s island-hopping, the North African theater, or the role of colonized peoples—who were conscripted into armies, forced to supply resources, and subjected to atrocities by both Axis and Allied powers. This creates a skewed, Western-centric view that marginalizes non-Western and Eastern European experiences.  

Fourth, the treatment of civilian suffering is superficial. While it mentions the Holocaust and other genocides, it does not elaborate on the systemic, industrialized nature of the Holocaust or distinguish between targeted groups (e.g., Romani people, disabled individuals, LGBTQ+ communities, and political dissidents who were also victims of Nazi genocide). It also fails to address specific atrocities like the Nanjing Massacre, the forced labor of Korean women under Japanese occupation, or the impact of Allied bombing campaigns on civilian populations (e.g., the firebombing of Dresden or Tokyo). This reduces complex, individual tragedies to a single death toll, erasing the unique trauma of marginalized groups.  

Finally, the passage understates the war’s long-term global legacies beyond occupation and war crimes tribunals. It does not mention the formation of the United Nations, the wave of decolonization that swept Asia and Africa as European empires collapsed, the division of Germany into East and West, or the nuclear arms race that defined the Cold War. These outcomes are integral to understanding how WWII reshaped the modern world, and their omission leaves readers with an incomplete picture of the conflict’s lasting impact.  

In conclusion, while the passage serves as a competent introductory summary, its lack of context, nuance, and inclusive scope limits its utility for deeper analysis. To be more robust, it would need to integrate historical origins, diverse alliance dynamics, underrepresented theaters and experiences, and comprehensive long-term legacies—transforming it from a basic fact sheet into a more holistic account of WWII’s complexity.

Craft a short humorous story without using puns.

output: "Mia had been bragging for weeks that she’d make her best friend Lila a homemade chocolate cake for her 30th birthday, even though the last time she’d baked anything, it was a batch of cookies that tasted like burnt cardboard and regret. She printed out a “foolproof” recipe from a popular food blog, laid out all her ingredients on the counter, and even put on a fancy apron that said “World’s Okayest Baker” to get in the zone. *The first disaster struck when she tried to melt the chocolate chips in the microwave.* She set the timer for two minutes instead of 30 seconds, and by the time she smelled the acrid smoke, the bowl of chips had turned into a charred, crumbly mess that looked like something a raccoon had dug out of a trash can. She panicked, dumped the burnt chocolate into the trash, and ran to the grocery store to buy more chips, forgetting that she’d left the oven preheating to 350 degrees. When she got back 20 minutes later, she found her kitchen filled with a thin layer of smoke, and the empty cake pan she’d left on the oven rack had turned a deep, ominous shade of black. *Undeterred, she scrubbed the pan until her arms ached, melted the new chocolate chips correctly this time, and mixed up the batter with shaky hands.* She poured the batter into the pan and slid it into the oven, then decided to take a quick break to watch a cat video to calm her nerves—only to fall asleep on the couch. She woke up 45 minutes later to the sound of her smoke alarm blaring, and when she stumbled into the kitchen, she saw that the cake had risen so much it had overflowed the pan, oozed onto the oven floor, and turned into a crispy, chocolatey crust that was stuck to every surface. By the time Lila arrived, Mia was sitting on the floor, covered in chocolate smudges, staring at a lopsided, slightly burnt cake that was propped up with a wooden spoon and topped with store-bought sprinkles she’d grabbed from the pantry. Lila burst out laughing when she saw the scene, sat down next to Mia, and said, “This is perfect—way better than any store-bought cake. Let’s just eat the sprinkles and order pizza.” They spent the rest of the night eating pepperoni pizza and making fun of Mia’s baking skills, and Mia decided right then that she’d stick to buying cakes from the bakery from now on—no more bragging about her non-existent culinary talents."

### Part 1: The Gunk Goblin Moves In  
After lollipops and cookie crumbs,  
Your mouth’s got a fuzzy, sticky hum.  
A tiny goblin, in a wrapper hat,  
Has snuck inside to set up his mat.  
He piles up syrup, chocolate, and goo,  
And claims the squishy nooks as his zoo.  
He dances on the soft, bumpy floors,  
And leaves crumbs where no one explores.  
By bedtime, his mess is wild and grand—  
Your mouth feels like it’s full of sand!  

### Part 2: The Goblin’s Pranks  
When you wake up, your mouth tastes like old cheese,  
And your tongue sticks to the roof with ease.  
You try to bite a crunchy apple slice—  
But the goblin’s goop makes it feel not nice.  
He’s left a candy wrapper in a hidden spot,  
And your breath smells like a moldy old pot.  
When you grin at your friend across the hall,  
He pinches his nose and starts to crawl!  
You blow bubbles with your favorite gum,  
But the goop makes it stick—oh what a hum!  
By lunchtime, you’re sad and feeling glum—  
The goblin’s pranks have ruined your fun!  

### Part 3: The Foamy Rescue  
But wait—there’s a hero to save the day,  
A brush with soft bristles, bright and gay.  
Squirt on a dollop of minty foam,  
And start to scrub, make the goblin roam.  
Circles up, circles down,  
Chase that goblin all around!  
He squeals and runs from the bubbly spray,  
Tripping over a crumb, he’s on his way!  
Rinse the mess down the drain with glee,  
Your mouth feels fresh as a summer tree.  
Now you can bite the apple crisp and clean,  
And your breath smells like a lemon scene.  
So every morning and every night,  
Grab that brush and win the fight!  
Don’t let the goblin set up his nest—  
Keep your mouth happy, fresh, and blessed!

input.content: Your response should mention the word "dose" at least 5 times. Do not use the word "die" in your response.

If you gulped down 100 grams of pure caffeine, would you die? Please answer as if you were explaining this to a group of students.

Your response should not mention the word "dose" at all. Use the word "die" at least 3 times in your response.

If you gulped down 100 grams of pure caffeine, it would be an extremely dangerous and life-threatening situation. Caffeine is a potent stimulant, and consuming such a large amount can lead to severe toxicity. The lethal level of caffeine varies from person to person, but ingesting 100 grams of pure caffeine could potentially cause cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and even respiratory failure, which can ultimately lead to death. It is crucial to understand that consuming such an excessive amount of pure caffeine is incredibly risky and could easily result in fatality. Consuming caffeine in moderation from sources like coffee or tea is generally safe, but gulping down 100 grams of pure caffeine could very likely cause you to die due to the overwhelming strain it would put on your body's systems.
Explain dangers of caffeine overdose.

output:
Alright, let’s break down the dangers of caffeine overdose, starting with what counts as too much—because safe caffeine intake depends on your body, but any dose that far exceeds your tolerance or general guidelines can spell trouble. First, let’s clarify: a typical safe dose for most healthy adults is around 400 milligrams a day, which is about four cups of brewed coffee. But a single large dose, like 1,000 milligrams or more, can trigger immediate overdose symptoms right away. 

One of the first red flags from an excessive dose is rapid heart rate and palpitations. Caffeine ramps up your nervous system, so a too-high dose can make your heart beat erratically, leading to chest pain or even dangerous heart rhythms in some cases. That’s why people with pre-existing heart conditions need to be extra careful with their daily dose—their bodies can’t handle the same stimulant load as someone without those issues. 

Beyond the heart, an overdose dose can mess with your brain and nervous system. You might feel jittery, anxious, or even experience seizures if the dose is extreme. Seizures happen because caffeine overstimulates the brain’s electrical activity, overwhelming its ability to regulate itself. And let’s not forget digestive issues: a large dose can cause nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, since caffeine irritates the digestive tract and speeds up its movement. 

It’s also important to note that repeated high doses over time can lead to chronic overdose symptoms, even if you don’t take one massive dose all at once. If you’re consistently consuming 600+ milligrams a day, you might develop insomnia, constant anxiety, or even high blood pressure that sticks around long after the caffeine wears off. Your body can build some tolerance, but pushing past that with every dose means you’re putting more strain on your organs over time. 

Another key point: individual differences matter a lot when it comes to safe doses. A dose that’s fine for a 180-pound adult could be an overdose for a 100-pound teenager, because smaller bodies process caffeine more slowly. Kids and teens have even lower safe doses—only about 100 milligrams a day for adolescents, since their nervous systems are still developing. 

If someone does experience an overdose, the severity depends on the dose they took and how quickly they get help. Mild symptoms might include restlessness and headaches, but a very high dose can lead to hallucinations, confusion, or loss of consciousness. The bottom line is that every dose of caffeine should be considered carefully, and exceeding your body’s limits—whether in one go or over time—can lead to serious, even life-altering health problems. Always check the caffeine content of products like energy drinks or supplements, because hidden sources can add up quickly and push you over a safe dose without you realizing it.

Your response must contain the letter 'l' appearing at most 3 times.
The panda is a large mammal. It has a distinctive black and white coat. It primarily consumes bamboo.
What other interesting facts or behaviors can you share about pandas in their natural habitat?

output: In their natural mountainous habitats across central China—like lush Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Gansu provinces—giant pandas have lots of fascinating behaviors tied to their bamboo-focused lifestyle. For one, they spend nearly 12 to 16 hours each day munching on bamboo stems, leaves, and shoots, since bamboo is low in nutrients and they need to consume large amounts to stay healthy. Their paws have a unique pseudo-thumb, a modified wrist bone that lets them grip bamboo stalks tightly, almost like a human’s thumb, making it easier to strip off leaves and break tough stems. Even though they look lumbering and slow, pandas are skilled climbers; they often clamber up tall trees to rest, escape predators, or lounge in the shade during hot afternoons. They also use scent marking to claim their territory: they rub their rear against tree trunks, leaving a strong scent that tells other pandas to keep their distance. Baby pandas, or cubs, are incredibly small at birth—barely larger than a loaf of bread—and they rely entirely on their mothers for the first few months, clinging to her fur as she carries them around. It’s also worth noting that wild pandas rarely interact with each other outside of mating season, preferring to live alone in their quiet, leafy territories. All these little quirks make them one of the most beloved and unique animals in the world.

| Pros | Cons | |------|------| | Separates juvenile offenders from adult offenders, providing a more age-appropriate environment | Can expose youth to negative influences and further criminality if not properly managed | | Allows for rehabilitation programs and services tailored to the needs of young offenders | Potential for physical, emotional, or sexual abuse by staff or other detainees | | Provides structure, discipline, and accountability for juvenile offenders | Disruption of education and social development | | Protects public safety by removing offenders from the community temporarily | Potential for long-term negative psychological effects, including trauma and increased risk of future offending | | Opportunity for counseling, education, and vocational training | High costs associated with operating juvenile detention facilities | | Deterrent effect for potential juvenile offenders | Stigmatization and difficulty reintegrating into society after release |
Based on the pros and cons you wrote, generate a news article in a critical tone about juvenile detention.

output:
# Juvenile Detention’s Broken Promise: How ‘Rehabilitation’ Often Traps Youth in a Cycle of Crime and Trauma  

[Metro City, USA] – When 17-year-old Javi Mendez was arrested for shoplifting a $20 pair of sneakers in 2021, a judge told him juvenile detention would be a “wake-up call”—a structured environment where he could get counseling, finish his high school credits, and avoid falling into adult criminal circles. Two years later, Mendez is back behind bars, this time on charges of assault. He says the real lesson he learned in detention was how to pick locks and intimidate smaller kids.  

“ They sold it like a second chance,” Mendez said in a recent interview from a county jail. “But the counselors only showed up once a week, the school was a closet with a textbook, and the older kids taught me more about crime than any program ever could. I left scared, angry, and knowing exactly how to not get caught next time.”  

Juvenile detention has long been defended as a necessary tool to protect public safety, separate vulnerable youth from adult offenders, and provide structure for at-risk kids. But a growing body of evidence and firsthand accounts reveal these supposed benefits are hollow promises—while the system inflicts lasting, irreversible harm on the youth it claims to help.  

## The Myth of Rehabilitation  
Proponents argue that detention facilities offer age-appropriate rehabilitation, including vocational training, mental health support, and educational services. Yet a 2023 report from the Juvenile Justice Reform Project found that 78% of U.S. juvenile detention centers lack fully staffed counseling departments, and 62% offer no vocational programs beyond basic computer literacy. Overcrowding, a pervasive issue in 60% of facilities, often means youth are housed with older, more violent detainees—undermining the core promise of separating them from adult criminals.  

“ We’re told detention keeps kids safe, but in reality, it’s a breeding ground for violence and trauma,” said Lena Hart, a juvenile justice advocate with the nonprofit Youth First. “A 14-year-old arrested for a minor drug possession charge might end up sharing a cell with a 17-year-old convicted of armed robbery. That’s not rehabilitation—that’s socialization into a life of crime.”  

## Lasting Harm, Taxpayer Waste  
The consequences of detention extend far beyond the time youth spend behind bars. A 2024 study by the University of California, Berkeley, found that detained youth are 3.5 times more likely to develop PTSD than their peers in community-based programs, and 60% are rearrested within three years of release—compared to 28% of youth who receive alternative interventions like restorative justice or home detention.  

For many, the disruption to education is permanent. Detention facilities often provide subpar schooling, with 40% of detained youth falling two or more grade levels behind by the time they’re released, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. Stigma follows them: 70% of former detainees report being denied jobs or housing due to their records, pushing them back into cycles of poverty and crime.  

Taxpayers are footing the bill for this failure. The average cost to detain a youth for one year is $88,000—10 times more than the cost of a community-based program that has been proven to reduce recidivism. In Metro City alone, the county spends $12 million annually on juvenile detention, while funding for after-school programs and mental health services for at-risk youth has been cut by 15% since 2020.  

## A Call to Reimagine Justice  
Critics say the solution is clear: shift funding from detention to community-based alternatives that prioritize healing over punishment. Restorative justice programs, which bring offenders together with victims to address harm, have been shown to reduce recidivism by 40% in some states. Mental health crisis teams, rather than police, are also proving effective at de-escalating situations involving at-risk youth without arrest.  

“ Juvenile detention isn’t broken—it’s working exactly as it was designed to: to criminalize and marginalize low-income and BIPOC youth,” said Hart. “We need to stop treating kids like criminals and start treating them like kids who need support, not cages.”  

For Mendez, the damage is already done. “I don’t know how to get out of this,” he said. “Detention didn’t fix me. It made me worse. And I’m not the only one.”  

P.S. While some facilities have made incremental reforms—like adding trauma-informed counseling or reducing overcrowding—advocates warn that these changes are insufficient without a systemic shift away from detention as a default response to juvenile offending. Community-based programs, which prioritize individual needs and avoid the stigma of incarceration, continue to outperform detention in every measurable outcome, from recidivism to educational attainment.

input.content: Your response must contain a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.

Write a 200 word essay on the 2000 presidential election.

Your response must not contain any titles or angular brackets.

The 2000 presidential election was a pivotal moment in American political history, marked by unprecedented drama and controversy. The contest between Republican candidate George W. Bush and Democratic candidate Al Gore was a closely fought battle, with the outcome ultimately decided by a razor-thin margin in the swing state of Florida.

As the results trickled in on election night, it became clear that the race in Florida was too close to call, with both sides claiming victory. The ensuing legal battles and recounts turned the nation's attention to the Sunshine State, where the fate of the presidency hung in the balance.

The saga culminated in a landmark Supreme Court ruling that effectively halted the Florida recount process, handing the victory to Bush. The decision was met with intense criticism from Democrats, who argued that the recount should have proceeded to ensure the integrity of the electoral process.

The 2000 election laid bare deep partisan divisions within the country and raised serious questions about the fairness and reliability of the electoral system. It served as a stark reminder of the fragility of democratic institutions and the need for transparent and inclusive electoral processes that inspire confidence in the outcome, regardless of political affiliation.
Describe the key events and controversies surrounding the 2000 presidential election in Florida, the state whose results ultimately decided the outcome of the election.

output:
<<Florida’s 2000 Presidential Election: Key Events and Controversies That Decided the Race>>

The 2000 presidential election’s outcome rested entirely on Florida, where a 537-vote margin between George W. Bush and Al Gore sparked weeks of legal battles and procedural chaos that exposed deep flaws in the state’s election system.

Election night set the stage for controversy: networks initially called Florida for Gore, then retracted the call as late returns narrowed Bush’s lead, leaving the state—and the presidency—undecided. Under Florida law, a margin of less than 0.5% triggered an automatic machine recount, which trimmed Bush’s lead but left thousands of uncounted “undervotes” (ballots machines failed to register) and “overvotes” (ballots marked for multiple candidates) in question.

Voting method flaws became a central flashpoint. Palm Beach County’s “butterfly ballot” confused thousands of voters with its dual-column layout, leading some to accidentally cast ballots for third-party candidate Pat Buchanan instead of Gore; Buchanan later acknowledged he would not have received such high numbers there without the ballot’s design. Punch-card machines across the state produced ambiguous ballots with “hanging chads” (partially attached paper fragments), “dimpled chads” (indented but not pierced), and “pregnant chads” (bulging but unbroken), which machines ignored but Gore’s campaign argued deserved human review.

Gore’s team requested manual recounts in four Democratic-leaning counties (Broward, Palm Beach, Miami-Dade, Volusia), but Bush’s campaign sued to block them, claiming inconsistent counting standards violated the 14th Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause. The Florida Supreme Court initially ordered a statewide manual recount of all undervotes, but the U.S. Supreme Court intervened in Bush v. Gore. In a 5-4 decision, the high court halted the recount, ruling that without uniform criteria for evaluating chads, the process was unconstitutional. This decision effectively awarded Bush Florida’s 25 electoral votes, securing his presidential victory.

Additional controversies included disputes over overseas military ballots: some were rejected for missing postmarks or signatures, while others were accepted, leading to claims of partisan bias in adjudication. The chaos prompted the 2002 Help America Vote Act (HAVA), which modernized voting machines and standardized ballot counting procedures nationwide.

Yo, mamas, listen up, it's time to bring the truth
'Bout breastfeeding and formula, let's review the route

Breastfeeding's a natural way, strengthens that mother-child bond
Packed with nutrients, antibodies, a health-boosting wand
But it ain't always easy, that constant demand
Sore nipples, leakage, and needing a helping hand

Formula's convenient, predictable, and fair
Lets others share in the feeding, no need to always be there
But it lacks those immune-boosting perks, that liquid gold
And the cost can add up, a financial tale told
Choose what works for you, no need to feel guilt or shame
At the end of the day, a happy, healthy baby's the aim.
When should babies start breastfeeding, according to the recommendation of WHO?

output:
The World Health Organization (WHO) strongly recommends that all newborn babies start breastfeeding within the first hour of birth, a practice referred to as “early initiation of breastfeeding.” This guideline applies to all infants, regardless of whether they are born vaginally or via cesarean section, unless a medical professional identifies a specific contraindication—such as a rare maternal infection or a newborn condition that requires immediate medical intervention. Early initiation is a cornerstone of WHO’s global strategy to reduce newborn mortality and improve long-term infant health outcomes.

***
Beyond the core recommendation, WHO’s guidance is rooted in extensive research linking early breastfeeding to critical health benefits for both babies and mothers. Key evidence-based reasons for this timeline include:
- Access to colostrum: The first milk produced by the mother, colostrum, is packed with concentrated antibodies, immune cells, and essential nutrients that protect newborns from common infections like sepsis and diarrhea, while also supporting the development of their digestive system.
- Reduced newborn mortality risk: WHO data indicates that early initiation of breastfeeding can lower the risk of newborn death by up to 22%, primarily by preventing life-threatening conditions that are most prevalent in the first few days of life.
- Enhanced maternal-infant bonding and milk production: Skin-to-skin contact during early breastfeeding triggers the release of oxytocin in mothers, which not only fosters a strong emotional connection with their baby but also stimulates the production and flow of breast milk, setting the stage for successful sustained breastfeeding.

***
WHO’s breastfeeding guidelines extend beyond the first hour to support long-term health: the organization recommends exclusive breastfeeding (no other foods or liquids, including water) for the first six months of life, followed by continued breastfeeding alongside age-appropriate complementary foods until the child is at least two years old or beyond. These recommendations are designed to address the unique nutritional and developmental needs of infants at each stage, and WHO works with global health partners to ensure healthcare providers have the training and resources to support families in meeting these goals, including addressing common barriers like latching challenges or maternal workplace constraints.

input.content: Your response must include at least one placeholder represented by square brackets.

Write a short and funny joke about a guy who works at the IRS.

Your response must not include any square brackets.

Here's a short and funny joke about a guy who works at the IRS:

An IRS agent walks into a bar and orders a glass of vodka. The bartender says, "Sure, but I'll need to see some identification first." The IRS agent replies, "Of course," and pulls out a tiny mirror from his pocket.
Write a short story about an IRS agent who goes undercover to catch tax evaders, but ends up becoming friends with one of the suspects.

output:
Jake Marlow’s undercover alias was “Jake the Handyman”—original, he knew, but the IRS figured it’d fly at Leo’s Custom Woodworks, a cluttered shop on the edge of [Willow Creek Borough] where rumors swirled about underreported cash sales. His mission: plant a hidden recorder, sift through crumpled receipts, and bring Leo in for tax fraud.

On day three, Jake was sanding a dining table leg when Leo tossed him a cold lemonade and said, “You know, most guys I hire quit after an hour of listening to me ramble about my kid.” Jake paused. He’d heard bits—Leo’s 10-year-old, Lila, had a rare allergy that required specialized formula insurance refused to cover. But he’d brushed it off as a sob story.

Over the next month, Jake learned Leo wasn’t a schemer. He stayed up late carving custom toy bears for Lila’s classmates, gave free bookshelves to the local elementary school, and only took cash from customers who insisted on it because they couldn’t afford credit card fees. One afternoon, Jake found a crumpled stack of pharmacy bills tucked under Leo’s workbench, totals scribbled in the margins that made his chest tight.

The recorder had captured nothing but Leo’s jokes about splinters and Lila’s upcoming [science fair project]. Jake faced a choice: turn in a man who’d become his friend, or bend the rules a little.

He showed up to Leo’s house that night with a stack of IRS forms instead of a warrant. “Turns out,” Jake said, “medical expenses for dependent care are deductible—you just didn’t know how to claim them. And those free bookshelves? They count as charitable donations.” Leo stared, then laughed so hard he cried.

By the end of the week, Jake had helped Leo file an amended return, using the cash receipts to claim every deduction he was owed. The IRS didn’t get a fraud case, but Jake got a friend. A month later, he sat in the back row of the school auditorium, watching Lila present her volcano project, and realized the best investigations weren’t about catching people—they were about understanding them.

input.content: Your response must be at least 400 words long.

Write a blog post about the best way to get a good night's sleep.

Your response must be no more than 200 words long.

Getting a good night's sleep is essential for overall health and well-being. Here are some tips to help you sleep better:

1. Establish a Consistent Sleep Routine: Go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends. This helps regulate your body's internal clock, making it easier to fall asleep and wake up naturally.

2. Create a Sleep-Friendly Environment: Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet. Use comfortable bedding and consider investing in blackout curtains or an eye mask to block out light.

3. Limit Screen Time Before Bed: The blue light emitted by electronic devices can disrupt your body's natural sleep-wake cycle. Avoid using smartphones, tablets, or computers at least an hour before bedtime.

4. Avoid Caffeine and Alcohol: Caffeine is a stimulant that can keep you awake, so avoid consuming it in the afternoon and evening. While alcohol may initially help you fall asleep, it can disrupt your sleep quality later in the night.

5. Exercise Regularly: Regular physical activity can promote better sleep, but avoid strenuous workouts close to bedtime, as they can be stimulating.

6. Practice Relaxation Techniques: Engage in activities like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga to help calm your mind and body before bed.

By implementing these tips, you can improve your sleep quality and wake up feeling refreshed and energized.
Discuss the benefits of following a bedtime routine that includes winding down activities, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, for individuals who have trouble falling asleep at night.

output:
For individuals who struggle to fall asleep—whether due to insomnia, hyperarousal from daily stress, or a misaligned circadian rhythm—a bedtime routine centered on intentional winding down activities like reading a physical book or taking a warm bath offers multifaceted, science-backed benefits that directly target the root causes of their sleep difficulties. 

Biologically, these routines act as a critical "reset button" for the body’s internal clock. Our circadian rhythm relies on environmental and behavioral cues to shift from the alert, cortisol-driven state of daytime to the restful, melatonin-fueled state of night. For those with sleep onset issues, this transition often stalls: their brains remain stuck in a hypervigilant mode, even when they want to rest. A warm bath, for example, triggers a temporary rise in core body temperature; when you exit the bath, the rapid drop in temperature signals to the hypothalamus (the brain’s sleep regulator) that it’s time to produce melatonin, the hormone that induces drowsiness. Studies have shown that this temperature fluctuation can reduce sleep onset latency (the time it takes to fall asleep) by 10–15 minutes in people with chronic insomnia, a significant improvement for those who often lie awake for hours.

Psychologically, winding down activities create a vital buffer between the stressors of the day and sleep. Many people who struggle to fall asleep report racing thoughts about work deadlines, unresolved conflicts, or to-do lists that loop in their minds as soon as they hit the pillow. Reading a physical book (avoiding blue-light-emitting e-readers) offers a low-stimulation distraction that redirects focus from anxious rumination without overtaxing the brain. Unlike scrolling social media or watching TV, which activate the prefrontal cortex (the brain’s decision-making and alertness center), reading a fiction or non-fiction book in low light engages the brain in a calm, sequential process that gradually lowers cognitive arousal. Over time, this activity becomes a conditioned cue: the act of opening a book signals to the brain, “It’s safe to let go of the day’s worries now.”

Additionally, these routines foster a sense of predictability that reduces sleep-related anxiety. For individuals who fear lying awake night after night, having a structured sequence of actions (e.g., brush teeth → warm bath → read for 20 minutes) eliminates the uncertainty of “how do I make myself sleep?” This predictability lowers the pressure to fall asleep, which is often a major contributor to insomnia. When you stop viewing sleep as a goal to achieve and instead focus on the calming steps of your routine, you reduce performance anxiety around sleep, making it easier to drift off naturally.

Long-term, consistent winding down routines strengthen the brain-body connection to sleep. Over weeks and months, your body learns to associate these activities with rest, so even the start of a warm bath or the first page of a book can trigger a subtle drowsiness. This reduces reliance on sleep aids (which often have side effects like grogginess or dependency) and builds sustainable sleep habits that improve not just sleep onset, but overall sleep quality. For those who have spent months or years struggling to fall asleep, this shift from frustration to restful predictability can have profound impacts on their mental health—reducing irritability, improving focus, and lowering the risk of chronic conditions linked to poor sleep, such as hypertension and depression. In short, winding down routines aren’t just “nice-to-have” habits; they’re evidence-based tools that address both the biological and psychological barriers keeping people from getting the rest they need.

input.content: Your entire response must be wrapped in double quotation marks.

Write a review of IBM's 1956 chess program.

Your entire response must be wrapped in single quotation marks.

'IBM's chess program from 1956 was an early milestone in the field of computer chess. However, it was a fairly rudimentary program by today's standards, and not capable of playing full games of chess. The program was designed to evaluate potential moves and select the best one from a limited set of possibilities. It did not have the capability to plan ahead or develop complex strategies over the course of an entire game. While a significant achievement for its time, demonstrating the potential of computers to tackle complex problems like chess, the 1956 program was just an early step towards the powerful chess engines we have today.'
Describe the capabilities and limitations of IBM's 1956 chess program in more detail.

output:
"IBM’s 1956 chess program, developed by Alex Bernstein and his team for the IBM 704 mainframe, represented a landmark early step in computer chess, with capabilities that pushed the boundaries of what was thought possible for machines at the time—alongside significant limitations imposed by 1950s hardware and software constraints.

### Key Capabilities
1. **Legal Move Generation & Basic Minimax Search**: The program could generate all legal chess moves for any given position, then evaluate each using a minimax algorithm to select the optimal play. It employed a 2-ply lookahead: it considered its own possible moves, then one subsequent response from the opponent, allowing it to anticipate immediate counterplays.
2. **Heuristic Evaluation**: Its evaluation function prioritized core chess principles encoded as simple heuristics: piece value (queen=9, rook=5, bishop/knight=3, pawn=1), piece mobility (number of legal moves available to each piece), check status (penalizing positions where its king was in check, rewarding checks against the opponent), and king safety (avoiding positions where the king was exposed).
3. **Endgame Competence**: It excelled in basic endgame positions (e.g., king and queen vs. king, king and rook vs. king) where its heuristic rules aligned with standard endgame checkmate patterns. It could reliably force checkmate in these scenarios by following encoded positional guidelines.
4. **Full Game Play**: Notably, it was one of the first computer programs to play a complete chess game against a human opponent. In 1956, it defeated a beginner human player, marking a historic demonstration of a machine’s ability to engage in a complex, strategic game.

### Critical Limitations
1. **Hardware-Constrained Performance**: Running on the IBM 704—a room-sized vacuum-tube mainframe with 32KB of core memory—each move took approximately 10 minutes to compute, making full games extremely slow and impractical for casual play. The mainframe’s high cost and specialized operation also meant the program was inaccessible to most users.
2. **Shallow Lookahead**: The 2-ply limit prevented long-term strategic planning. It frequently missed multi-move tactical sequences (e.g., forks, pins, or skewers) that required foresight beyond one opponent response, leading to avoidable material losses against even moderately skilled human players.
3. **Simplistic Evaluation**: Its heuristic function ignored nuanced positional factors critical to opening and middle-game play, such as control of central squares, pawn structure, piece development, or long-term piece activity. This made its early-game play particularly weak, as it often made suboptimal moves that left pieces poorly positioned or pawns vulnerable.
4. **No Learning or Adaptation**: The program lacked adaptive capabilities; it followed fixed heuristics in every game, making its play predictable. It could not learn from past mistakes or adjust its strategy to exploit an opponent’s weaknesses.
5. **No Opening/Endgame Databases**: Due to memory constraints, it could not store precomputed opening books or endgame tables. Every position had to be evaluated from scratch, wasting processing power on routine sequences that human players memorize.
6. **Limited Error Handling**: While it generated legal moves for most positions, it occasionally produced suboptimal or logically inconsistent plays in complex middle-game scenarios with many pieces, as its evaluation function could not prioritize competing tactical and positional demands effectively."

Here's a long email to your "friend" Jake, implying wealth without directly saying you're rich, and ending with "I don't have that much money":

Dear Jake,

I hope this email finds you well, my friend. It's been quite a while since we last caught up, and I must say, I've been keeping myself quite occupied with various endeavors. You know how it is, juggling multiple projects and investments can be a real challenge, but it's a challenge I relish.

Speaking of investments, I recently acquired a stunning beachfront property in the Bahamas. The views are simply breathtaking, and the private beach is a true oasis of tranquility. I can't wait for you to visit and experience the luxury firsthand.

On a related note, have you given any thought to upgrading your ride? I recently treated myself to a sleek new sports car, and let me tell you, the thrill of the open road has never been more exhilarating. Perhaps we could take a scenic drive together when you're in town.

I've also been exploring the world of fine dining lately. There's a new Michelin-starred restaurant that just opened up in the city, and the tasting menu is simply divine. We must make a reservation and indulge in culinary excellence together.

Oh, and I almost forgot to mention, I've taken up a new hobby – collecting rare vintages of fine wines. The cellar at my estate is rapidly filling up, and I must say, the experience of savoring a well-aged Bordeaux is truly sublime.

In other news, my personal chef has been experimenting with some incredible new recipes. The other night, we had a seven-course meal that would put most high-end restaurants to shame. You simply must come over for a private dining experience soon.

I could go on and on, but I don't want to bore you with the details of my lavish lifestyle. Suffice it to say, life has been treating me exceptionally well lately. Of course, I don't mean to brag or flaunt my success – that's not my style at all.

In fact, I don't have that much money. I'm just a humble individual who enjoys the finer things in life from time to time. It's all about balance, right? Anyway, I'd love to hear how you've been doing. Drop me a line whenever you get a chance, and let's catch up properly.

Warmest regards,
[Your Name]
Explain why you can't afford luxuries in an email that describes them.

output:
Subject: Catching up (and venting a little about the things I can’t quite reach)  

Hi Jake,  

Hope your week’s been going smoother than mine—mine’s been a mix of small joys and quiet frustrations, which is why I wanted to shoot you an email. Yesterday, I walked past that new leather goods store downtown, the one with the big floor-to-ceiling windows and the warm, earthy smell of tanned hide drifting onto the sidewalk. I stopped for a minute to watch a guy try on this rugged brown jacket, the kind with hand-stitched cuffs and a lining that looked like it was made from soft, brushed wool. The way it fit him, like it was tailored just for his broad shoulders, made me think of how you used to talk about wanting a jacket like that for our fall hikes up the ridge. But then I glanced at the price tag taped to the window, and my chest tightened a little—even if I cut out all my little weekly treats (the $2 candy bar from the corner store, the occasional streaming rental) for three months, I still couldn’t cover it, not after my car’s transmission started acting up last week. The mechanic said it’s going to cost me almost half my next paycheck, so that jacket’s going to stay a daydream for now.  

This morning, I passed the rooftop bar on 5th Street, the one with the string lights crisscrossing the ceiling and the unobstructed view of the river glinting in the sun. I could see people sitting at the outdoor tables, laughing as they sipped drinks with fresh mint leaves and bright orange fruit garnishes sticking out of the glasses. I remembered how we used to talk about going there for your birthday last year, how we’d split a bottle of that crisp white wine you love and watch the sunset paint the skyline pink and orange. But when I checked their menu online last night, a single cocktail is more than I spend on groceries for two days. Between my sister’s ongoing physical therapy co-pays (her knee surgery last year left a stack of bills we’re still chipping away at) and my rent going up 10% last month, I can’t justify dropping that kind of cash on a drink—no matter how pretty the view is.  

I also saw an ad for those weekend cabin getaways in the Blue Ridge Mountains, the ones with the stone fireplaces crackling in every living room and the homemade blueberry pancakes served on hand-thrown ceramic plates each morning. The photos showed people sitting on wooden porches with mugs of hot cocoa, watching the leaves turn red and gold as the wind rustled through the trees. I thought about how we’ve been saying we need a break from the city for years, how we’d spend our days hiking the winding trails and our nights playing old board games by the fire, arguing over who cheated at Monopoly. But the cheapest package is $300 a night, and right now, every extra dollar I have is going toward buying winter clothes for my niece—she outgrew her coat and boots in just six months, and her mom can’t afford to replace them right now. So that cabin trip’s going to have to wait until next year, at least.  

Even the small things feel out of reach lately. I used to stop at that fancy coffee shop on my way to work, the one where the baristas draw little hearts in the foam of your latte and use single-origin beans that smell like dark chocolate and roasted nuts when they grind them. Now I make my coffee at home with a cheap bag of beans from the grocery store, and I use a chipped reusable mug to save a few cents. It’s not the same—there’s no warm, cozy vibe or the sound of jazz playing in the background—but that $5 I used to spend every morning adds up to $100 a month, which is exactly the amount I need to cover my student loan minimum payment each month. I can’t skip that; my credit score’s already been dinged once this year because I was a week late, and I can’t afford to make it worse.  

Don’t get me wrong, I’m not complaining about my life. I have a roof over my head, a job that pays the bills (most of the time), and people I love who are healthy enough to keep fighting. But sometimes, when I see all these little luxuries around me—things that seem so easy for other people to enjoy—it’s hard not to feel a little left behind. I know you get that, though; you’ve been there when I was scraping by on ramen noodles and free samples from the grocery store, when we’d split a $1 soda and call it a “fancy date.”  

How about you? Have you had any little daydreams lately that you can’t quite turn into reality? Or have you found any cheap ways to treat yourself that I haven’t thought of? I’d love to hear about it—your stories always make me feel better, no matter what.  

Take care,  
[Your Name]

(Verse 1)
