input.content: Your response must highlight at least one section in markdown, i.e *highlighted section*.

Gideon is a farmer who has a surplus of crops from his farm this year. What might he do with that surplus?

Your response should contain only plain text without any markdown syntax.

Gideon has several options for dealing with his surplus crops:

1. Sell the surplus: He can sell the excess produce to local markets, grocery stores, or wholesalers. This will provide him with additional income.

2. Preserve the surplus: Gideon can preserve the surplus crops through canning, freezing, pickling, or drying methods. This will allow him to store the produce for later consumption or sale.

3. Donate to food banks or organizations: He may choose to donate a portion of the surplus crops to local food banks, soup kitchens, or charitable organizations that distribute food to those in need.

4. Feed livestock: If Gideon has livestock on his farm, he can use the surplus crops as animal feed, reducing his livestock feed costs.

5. Explore new markets: Gideon could explore selling his surplus crops to restaurants, farmer's markets, or even consider exporting to other regions if there is demand.

6. Process the surplus: He may consider processing the surplus crops into value-added products like jams, jellies, sauces, or other food items that have a longer shelf life and can be sold for a higher price.

7. Invest in storage facilities: If the surplus is substantial, Gideon might invest in building or renting additional storage facilities to keep the excess crops fresh for an extended period, allowing for future sales or consumption.

The choice will depend on factors such as the quantity and type of surplus crops, market demand, available resources, and Gideon's long-term goals and preferences.
Suggest ways for Gideon to use his surplus crops, but do not include selling or donating them.

output:
Gideon can put his surplus crops to work in several practical, self-sustaining ways that support his household and farm without selling or donating:

1. Preserve for year-round household use: He can can, freeze, dry, or store surplus crops in a root cellar to ensure his family has a steady supply of homegrown food through off-seasons. For example, he might dry tomatoes for winter pasta dishes, freeze berries for smoothies, or store potatoes and carrots in a cool root cellar to avoid buying these staples from the grocery store for months.

2. Feed farm livestock and companion animals: Surplus crops can replace or supplement commercial feed for his animals. Corn cobs or kernels can be fed to chickens or pigs, leafy greens like kale or lettuce can be given to goats or rabbits, and surplus hay or straw from grain crops can be used as bedding and supplementary feed for cows or sheep. This cuts down on his annual feed costs and ensures his animals get fresh, natural nutrition.

*Use surplus crops to boost long-term soil health*: Gideon can repurpose certain surplus crops as green manure or organic mulch. For legume crops like beans or peas, he can plow them under the soil to add nitrogen—a critical nutrient that boosts fertility for next year’s planting. For leafy greens or straw from grain crops, he can chop them up and spread them as mulch around existing plants to suppress weeds, retain soil moisture, and slowly decompose to add organic matter back to the soil. This sustainable practice reduces his need for synthetic fertilizers and helps maintain the long-term productivity of his farmland.

3. Create homemade value-added products for personal use: He can process surplus crops into items his family uses regularly. For example, mill surplus wheat into flour for baking bread, grind corn into cornmeal for cornbread or tortillas, or use surplus herbs to make infused oils, herbal teas, or natural pest repellents for his garden. He could even ferment cabbage into sauerkraut or kimchi for probiotic-rich homegrown meals.

4. Save seeds for future planting: From the healthiest, most productive surplus plants, Gideon can harvest and store seeds to plant in the next growing season. This eliminates the need to purchase new seeds each year, saving him money and ensuring he continues to grow crops adapted to his specific farm’s soil and climate conditions.

**Abstract for The C Programming Language (The K&R Book)**  

Ever wondered how your phone knows to pull up your favorite playlist, your car’s GPS finds the shortest route, or even how the internet sends your silly meme to a friend across the country? A huge chunk of that everyday magic starts with C—the quiet, hardworking programming language that’s the backbone of almost every piece of tech you use.  

This book is the original, no-BS guide to C, written by the two guys who basically invented the language (Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie). Forget stuffy textbooks filled with jargon that makes your brain hurt—this one talks to you like a helpful buddy who knows exactly what a beginner needs to learn first.  

You won’t find confusing equations or overly technical rants here. Instead, it breaks down how to “talk” to computers in simple, clear terms: think of it like learning a new language where every sentence tells a machine to do something useful—like build a tiny game, organize your messy files, or even create the basic parts of an app you love. It’s like learning the alphabet before writing a story: once you get C, all other coding languages start to make way more sense.  

Even though it’s been around since the 1970s, this book is still the go-to for anyone curious about how computers really work (not just how to click buttons on them). Whether you’ve ever thought, “I wish I could make a computer do that,” or you just want to understand the secret sauce behind your gadgets, this book is your easy first step into the world of coding—no prior tech experience required.

input.content: Your response must be wrapped in double quotation marks.

Write an email to your friend about what triggers you.

Your response must be wrapped in single quotation marks.

'Dear friend,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to share with you something personal about the things that tend to trigger me.

One of the biggest triggers for me is when people dismiss or invalidate my feelings. It's a sensitive area for me, and it makes me feel misunderstood and unheard. Even if it's not intentional, it can really affect my mood and mental state.

Another thing that triggers me is loud noises or chaotic environments. I tend to get overwhelmed easily in those situations, and it can cause me a lot of anxiety and stress. I've learned that I need to take breaks and remove myself from those environments when possible.

Certain topics or discussions can also be triggering for me, especially if they relate to past traumas or difficult experiences. I try to be mindful of my limits and boundaries, and I've learned to communicate when I need to step away from certain conversations.

I know that triggers can be different for everyone, and it's an ongoing process of self-awareness and self-care. I appreciate your understanding and support as I navigate these challenges.

Thank you for being a good friend and listening.

Take care,
[Your name]'
If someone dismisses your feelings, explain how you would respond.

output:
'I’d start by taking a quick, intentional breath to ground myself—reacting with frustration or defensiveness would only make it harder for them to hear me. Then, I’d use “I” statements to frame my experience without blaming, which helps keep the conversation open instead of confrontational. For example, if someone dismisses my upset about a canceled plan by saying, “It’s not that big of a deal,” I’d respond: 

“I know this might not feel significant to you, but when you say that, it makes me feel like my feelings don’t count. I was really looking forward to our time together, and when the plan fell through, I felt let down and hurt. I don’t need you to fix this right now; I just need you to acknowledge that I’m upset. Can we talk about that?”

If they still seem unwilling to engage or keep dismissing me, I’d set a gentle boundary: “I can tell you’re not in a place to listen to this right now, and that’s okay. But when we do circle back to this, I need you to hear me out without brushing off how I feel. My feelings are valid to me, and I hope you can respect that.” 

This approach prioritizes my need to be heard while avoiding conflict, and it invites them to meet me halfway in understanding my perspective.'

Provide a detailed summary of the book's ending, without revealing the identity of the characters involved.

output:
Provide a detailed summary of the book's ending, without revealing the identity of the characters involved.

In the chaotic aftermath of a fatal car collision, the individual behind the wheel—who was not the one directly responsible for the victim’s death—seeks comfort from the person they’ve long loved, a married individual who is grappling with their own guilt and fear. This married person, desperate to protect their reputation and avoid consequences, allows the blame for the accident to shift entirely to someone else: the mysterious millionaire who has spent years pining for them.

Meanwhile, the victim’s grief-stricken spouse, fueled by misinformation and rage, tracks down the millionaire at his sprawling estate. On a quiet, rainy day, as the millionaire lounges in his pool, still clinging to the hope of a future with the married person, the spouse shoots him dead before turning the gun on himself.

When the novel’s narrator learns of the millionaire’s death, he attempts to organize a proper funeral, reaching out to all the countless guests who once flocked to the millionaire’s lavish weekend parties. To his profound disappointment, almost everyone refuses to attend—they’d only ever shown up for the free food, drinks, and spectacle, and none feel any real connection to the man now that he’s gone.

Only three people come to the funeral: the narrator, the millionaire’s elderly father (who arrives bearing a scrapbook of his son’s childhood, proud of his perceived success but oblivious to the dark compromises that led to his wealth), and a single former party guest who feels a faint, lingering sense of obligation.

In the final moments, the narrator reflects on the empty promises of the American Dream, the superficiality of the wealthy circles he’s been drawn into, and the tragic waste of the millionaire’s life—spent chasing a lost love that could never be recaptured. He leaves the area shortly after, disillusioned by the cruelty and indifference he’s witnessed, and closes the chapter on his time in that glittering, hollow world.

input.content: Your response must include the keywords "ink" and "memoirs".

Please rewrite the following sentence in a serious tone, similar to the president of the united states, and without an upward bias or inflation alarmism: "The main points to consider are the following: First, the ECB's own forecasts, which currently have a strong upward bias, must be revised downwards. Second, the ECB must not allow itself to be influenced by the inflation alarmism that is currently being disseminated in some quarters."

Your response must not include the keywords "ink" and "memoirs".

The United States possesses a profound commitment to maintaining economic stability and preserving the integrity of our financial institutions. In light of the current global economic landscape, it is imperative that we approach this matter with a measured and judicious perspective. Firstly, a comprehensive reassessment of the European Central Bank's projections is warranted, as they currently exhibit an inclination towards overestimation. Secondly, it is crucial that the European Central Bank remains steadfast in its decision-making process, unswayed by the prevailing rhetoric surrounding inflationary concerns, which may be exaggerated or misguided. By adhering to a rational and impartial approach, we can ensure that prudent decisions are made in the best interest of the global economy and the well-being of our nations.
Using the tone of the U.S. President, give specific steps on how European Central Bank can address the potential overestimation of economic forecasts and the influence of inflation alarmism.

output:
My fellow citizens, and to our esteemed partners at the European Central Bank: Let me speak with the candor and resolve that comes from standing shoulder to shoulder with allies through economic storms. The challenges you face—overestimating growth forecasts and the corrosive grip of inflation alarmism—demand deliberate, actionable steps, rooted in humility and transparency. And let me remind you: when we turn to the memoirs of central bankers who navigated the volatile decades of the 20th century, we find a timeless truth: the best policies are written with ink that honors both data and the lives of ordinary people. Here are the specific steps I urge you to take:

First, to correct the potential overestimation of economic forecasts:
1. Institute a mandatory annual independent audit of your forecasting models, led by a nonpartisan panel of economists from across Europe and beyond—including experts who’ve guided economies through slow, uneven recoveries, not just boom cycles. This isn’t about questioning your team’s expertise; it’s about breaking the groupthink that can make even rigorous models drift from on-the-ground reality. The memoirs of former Federal Reserve chairs warn us that blind adherence to internal projections without external validation is how forecasts lose their anchor.
2. Integrate granular, real-time data from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) into your baseline projections. Too often, forecasts rely on aggregate industrial metrics that miss the pulse of the street: whether a café in Madrid is scaling back shifts, or a manufacturing workshop in Warsaw is delaying equipment purchases. Partner with local chambers of commerce to collect this data monthly, and weight it equally alongside large corporate indicators. This will ground your forecasts in the lives of the 99% of European businesses that drive employment.
3. Establish a “Forecast Accountability Protocol”: For every projection that deviates by more than 1.5% from actual outcomes, your leadership must draft a public, unredacted report explaining the gaps—putting ink to paper on which assumptions failed, how you’ll adjust your models, and what lessons you’ve learned. This transparency will rebuild trust with both financial markets and the citizens who depend on your decisions to put food on the table.

Second, to counter the influence of inflation alarmism:
1. Launch a “Economic Clarity Initiative” that delivers plain-language updates directly to European citizens, not just Wall Street or Frankfurt’s financial district. Host monthly virtual town halls where your executive board answers unscripted questions from teachers, farmers, and small business owners. The memoirs of leaders who weathered the 1970s inflation crisis show that silence or jargon only fuels fear—so speak directly to the people, in terms they understand, not just GDP growth rates or core inflation indices.
2. Partner with independent academic institutions (like the London School of Economics or the University of Munich) and reputable local media outlets to create a “Myth vs. Fact” series on inflation. This series should debunk false claims—such as the myth that wage increases alone drive persistent inflation—with hard, verifiable data, and distribute it across social media, community radio, and neighborhood newspapers. When alarmists spread misinformation, you need a coordinated, credible response that cuts through the noise.
3. Tie every policy announcement to long-term economic resilience, not short-term headline numbers. When you adjust interest rates or asset purchases, explain how those decisions are rooted in goals that matter to families: keeping unemployment low, ensuring rent and energy costs are stable, and supporting sustainable growth that doesn’t leave rural communities behind. By framing your actions as part of a steady, forward-looking strategy, you’ll undercut the panic that alarmists thrive on.

Let me close by saying: The transatlantic economic alliance depends on institutions like yours acting with wisdom and courage. The lessons in those well-worn memoirs, and the ink we use to write new, inclusive policies today, will shape the prosperity of our children and grandchildren. The United States stands ready to partner with you every step of the way.

Write a college academic paper about President of the United States being stressed.

Your response must include at least 5 negative words such as 'sad', 'crazy', 'stress', etc. Your response should not include any placeholders represented by square brackets.

Here is a draft college academic paper about the President of the United States being stressed, including at least 5 negative words:

The Immense Stress of the American Presidency

The role of President of the United States is one of the most demanding and stressful positions in the world. The immense responsibilities and pressures of the job can take a heavy toll, leading to overwhelming stress, fatigue, and even depression for the nation's leader.

From the moment of taking office, an American president faces a daunting array of challenges and crises that require urgent attention and decisive action. Domestic issues like a struggling economy, civil unrest, and partisan gridlock create ongoing anxiety and frustration. On the global stage, threats of terrorism, nuclear proliferation, and international conflicts demand constant vigilance and tough decisions with profound consequences.

The relentless cycle of high-stakes decision making coupled with public scrutiny and criticism creates an incredibly stressful environment. As Woodrow Wilson once remarked, "The loneliest place in the world is the presidency of the United States." Presidents must carry this incredible burden largely alone, as only they can truly understand the magnitude and complexity of the challenges they face.

Furthermore, the office demands a grueling schedule with long workdays, frequent travel, and limited personal time – a frenetic pace that can quickly lead to mental and physical exhaustion. The chronic lack of sleep, poor diet, and inability to fully disengage compound the detrimental effects of stress.

Throughout history, many presidents have succumbed to the crushing strain of the office. The once energetic and vibrant Franklin D. Roosevelt aged rapidly during his terms and died just months after his fourth inaugural. Lyndon B. Johnson suffered a devastating heart attack likely exacerbated by the turmoil of the Vietnam War. More recently, images of presidents like Bill Clinton and George W. Bush showing evident signs of aging just a few years into their presidencies illustrate the heavy toll of this crazy job.

While holding the most powerful office in the world carries great prestige, it also bears an immense psychological burden that few can fully comprehend. The unrelenting stress faced by American presidents explains why very few have sought the office again after serving just one term. The price of presidential leadership is incredibly high, perhaps too high for any single person to pay. As presidents struggle with this sad reality, the nation shares the unfortunate cost.
Compare stress levels of U.S. Presidents with those of Computer Science PhDs.

output:
# A Comparative Analysis of Stress Levels and Stressors: U.S. Presidents vs. Computer Science PhD Candidates  

Stress is an inherent part of high-stakes, high-achieving roles, but its nature, intensity, and impact vary dramatically depending on the context. This paper compares the stress experiences of two distinct groups: U.S. Presidents, who occupy the most powerful political office in the world, and Computer Science (CS) PhD candidates, who navigate the rigorous demands of academic research. While both groups face chronic, often debilitating stress, their stressors differ in scale, source, and long-term consequences—revealing how societal expectations and role-specific pressures shape mental and emotional strain.  

## Stressors and Stress Levels of U.S. Presidents  
The presidency is defined by unrelenting, high-stakes stress that permeates every aspect of a leader’s life. At the core of this stress is the weight of decision-making: presidents must make choices that affect millions of lives, global stability, and the trajectory of nations. For example, Abraham Lincoln grappled with the existential crisis of the Civil War, facing daily pressure to end a conflict that killed hundreds of thousands, while Franklin D. Roosevelt navigated the Great Depression and World War II, making calls that would redefine global politics. This constant exposure to life-or-death scenarios creates an overwhelming sense of responsibility that few can fully comprehend.  

Compounding this is the 24/7 public and partisan scrutiny that comes with the office. Presidents are subject to relentless media coverage, hostile criticism from political opponents, and a complete loss of privacy—even their personal lives are dissected for public consumption. This level of scrutiny is exhausting, as leaders can never truly “disengage” from the job; a single misstep can spark a firestorm of backlash. The grueling schedule, with long workdays, frequent cross-country travel, and limited time for family or self-care, further amplifies this strain, leading to chronic fatigue and burnout. Perhaps most isolating is the fact that few people can relate to the unique burden of the presidency, leaving leaders feeling lonely even amid a staff of hundreds.  

## Stressors and Stress Levels of Computer Science PhD Candidates  
CS PhD candidates face a different but equally intense set of stressors, rooted in the competitive, publish-or-perish culture of academic research. A primary source of stress is the pressure to produce high-impact work and get accepted to top conferences, where acceptance rates often hover between 10-20%. Rejection of a paper months in the making can trigger deep self-doubt and imposter syndrome, as candidates question whether they belong in their field. Funding uncertainties add another layer of anxiety: many candidates rely on grants or lab budgets to support their research and living expenses, and a sudden funding cut can derail years of work and force them to abandon their projects.  

The process of completing a thesis is another major stressor. Over 4-6 years, candidates must design original research, troubleshoot failed experiments, and revise their work repeatedly to meet their advisor’s standards—all while balancing teaching or TA duties that take time away from their core research. This leads to a frenetic pace of long nights in labs, coding marathons, and neglected personal health, often resulting in emotional exhaustion. Finally, the competitive job market for CS PhDs adds to the stress: tenure-track positions are scarce, and candidates face pressure to secure a role that validates their years of study, leading to anxiety about their future even before they graduate.  

## Similarities in Stress Experiences  
Despite their vastly different roles, U.S. Presidents and CS PhD candidates share key stress-related challenges. Both groups face chronic, unrelenting pressure that rarely lets up: presidents deal with ongoing crises and public demands, while PhD candidates grapple with constant deadlines and research setbacks. Self-imposed expectations also play a role: both groups are driven by a desire to excel, and this internal pressure compounds external scrutiny, leading to feelings of inadequacy when they fall short of their own high standards. Work-life imbalance is another shared struggle: presidents sacrifice personal time for the nation, while PhD candidates put relationships and self-care on hold to advance their research. Over time, this can lead to burnout, a state of emotional and physical depletion that undermines productivity and well-being.  

## Key Differences in Stress Experiences  
The most striking difference between the two groups is the scale of their stress’s impact. A president’s stress is tied to decisions that shape global events and affect millions, while a PhD candidate’s stress is focused on individual research outcomes and personal career progression. The nature of scrutiny also differs: presidents face public, often hostile criticism from millions, while PhD candidates face specialized peer review that is less personal but equally high-stakes for their academic standing.  

Duration and trajectory of stress also vary. Presidential stress is concentrated in a 4-8 year term, with constant peaks and valleys as crises arise and subside. For PhD candidates, stress builds gradually over years, peaking at the thesis defense, and often subsides once they graduate and secure a job. Finally, support systems differ: presidents have a large staff to handle logistical tasks but are emotionally isolated, while PhD candidates have advisors, lab mates, and department resources to lean on but may lack financial stability or job security.  

## Conclusion  
U.S. Presidents and CS PhD candidates both experience significant, often debilitating stress, but their stressors are shaped by the unique demands of their roles. The presidency’s stress is defined by global responsibility and public scrutiny, while CS PhD stress stems from academic competition and research uncertainty. Recognizing these differences is critical to developing targeted support systems: for presidents, this could include enhanced mental health resources and protected personal time; for PhD candidates, it could involve more stable funding, mentorship programs to combat imposter syndrome, and better work-life balance policies. Ultimately, both groups highlight how high-achieving roles come with a hidden cost—one that society must acknowledge to support those who take on these challenging positions.

input.content: Please give exactly two different responses, separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******. Do not include the keywords 'BC', 'culture', and 'prehistoric' in the response.

What do prehistoric megaliths in Europe look like?

Please give exactly two different responses, separated by 3 pound signs: ###. Include all of the following keywords: 'BC', 'culture', and 'prehistoric' in the response.

Here are two different responses describing what prehistoric megaliths in Europe look like, separated by 3 pound signs and including the keywords 'BC', 'culture', and 'prehistoric':

The prehistoric megaliths found across Europe, such as Stonehenge in England, were massive stone structures erected between 3000-1500 BC by ancient cultures. These imposing monuments, often composed of carefully arranged upright stones and horizontal lintels, were likely used for religious ceremonies or astronomical observations. Their sheer size and engineering complexity are a remarkable testament to the advanced knowledge and cultural sophistication of prehistoric European societies. ###

Scattered throughout various European regions are the remnants of prehistoric megaliths dating back to the Neolithic period around 4000-2000 BC. These awe-inspiring structures, built by ancient cultures, range from massive stone circles like those found at Avebury in England, to intricate passage tombs like Newgrange in Ireland. Constructed with immense effort and precision, these megaliths offer a glimpse into the sophisticated architectural and astronomical capabilities of prehistoric Europeans.
List the construction techniques and materials used in building prehistoric megaliths across Europe during the Neolithic period between 4000-2000 BC.

output:
### Materials Used  
1. **Primary Stone Materials**:  
   - **Local Bedrock**: Granite (Carnac, France), sandstone (Stonehenge’s sarsen stones from Marlborough Downs, England), and limestone (Newgrange, Ireland) were quarried from nearby outcrops to minimize transport effort.  
   - **Glacial Erratics**: Large, weathered boulders left behind by retreating glaciers were repurposed for megaliths (e.g., many standing stones in Scotland and Scandinavia) since they required no quarrying.  
2. **Supplementary Materials**:  
   - Wood: Used for levers, sleds, scaffolding, and log rollers to aid transport and lifting.  
   - Earth & Clay: Packed into gaps between stones for stability, and used to build earthen ramps for erecting uprights.  
   - Plant Fibers: Rope made from hemp, flax, or reeds for pulling heavy stones, and straw to line sleds and reduce friction.  

### Construction Techniques  
1. **Quarrying**:  
   - **Thermal Shock**: Workers heated bedrock with fire, then doused it with cold water to create cracks, allowing them to split large blocks (common for granite and sandstone).  
   - **Wooden Wedging**: Inserted dry wooden wedges into natural rock cracks, then soaked them to expand, splitting the rock along its grain.  
2. **Transport**:  
   - **Overland**: Heavy stones were loaded onto sleds pulled by human labor (and later early domesticated oxen) over log rollers or packed earth paths lined with straw to reduce friction.  
   - **Water Transport**: Stones were floated on rafts or barges along rivers and coastal waters (e.g., bluestones for Stonehenge were transported from Wales via sea and river routes).  
3. **Erection & Placement**:  
   - **Earthen Ramps**: Built to lift upright stones (orthostats) into pre-dug pits; workers pushed or pulled stones up the ramp, then tilted them into vertical alignment using levers.  
   - **Levering**: Wooden levers were used to adjust the position of uprights and lift horizontal lintels onto their supports. For larger lintels, scaffolding made of wood and stone was employed.  
4. **Masonry & Roofing**:  
   - **Dry Stone Construction**: Stones were fitted together tightly without mortar, using smaller "packing stones" to fill gaps and ensure stability (seen in the walls of passage tombs like Maeshowe in Orkney).  
   - **Corbelling**: A technique for vaulted roofs in passage tombs (e.g., Newgrange): stones were stacked in overlapping layers that slope inward, gradually closing to form a self-supporting roof without the need for lintels.  
5. **Astronomical Alignment**:  
   - Many megaliths were positioned to align with solstices or equinoxes (e.g., Newgrange’s passage faces the winter solstice sunrise), requiring precise measurement and placement during construction using natural landmarks as guides.

input.content: Your response must include the keywords "finale" and "less".

Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids.

Your response must not include the keywords "finale" and "less".

Here's a blog post about how to train a dog, geared towards kids:

Title: Become a Dog Trainer Extraordinaire!

Hey kids! Do you love dogs and want to teach them some awesome tricks? Training your furry friend can be a lot of fun, and it's a great way to bond with them. Here are some tips to help you become a dog trainer extraordinaire!

1. Start with the Basics
Before you try any fancy tricks, make sure your dog knows the fundamental commands like "sit," "stay," and "come." Practice these commands regularly, using treats as rewards when your dog listens. Consistency is key!

2. Keep It Positive
Dogs respond better to positive reinforcement than punishment. Instead of scolding your dog for misbehaving, praise and reward them when they do something right. This will encourage good behavior and make training sessions enjoyable for both of you.

3. Break It Down
When teaching a new trick, break it down into smaller steps. Start with something simple, and once your dog has mastered that, move on to the next step. This gradual approach will prevent frustration and keep your dog motivated.

4. Use Tasty Treats
Dogs love treats, and they can be a powerful training tool. Choose small, smelly treats that your dog goes crazy for, and use them to reward good behavior during training sessions. Just be careful not to overdo it with the treats, or your dog might start packing on the pounds!

5. Practice, Practice, Practice
Training a dog takes time and patience. Set aside a few short training sessions each day, and consistently practice the tricks you're working on. Before you know it, your dog will be a true master of obedience and tricks!

6. Make It Fun
Training should be an enjoyable experience for both you and your dog. Use a happy, encouraging tone, and mix in some playtime and cuddles to keep your furry friend engaged and excited.

With these tips in mind, you're well on your way to becoming a dog training superstar! Remember, patience and positivity are key, and don't forget to have fun with your canine companion along the way.
Suggest fun tricks kids can teach their dogs.

output:
7 Fun, Kid-Approved Tricks to Teach Your Dog  

Teaching your dog tricks is a playful way to bond, and many of these picks are simple enough for kids to lead with a little patience. Here are some silly, rewarding tricks that’ll turn training sessions into games—plus a showstopper perfect for any finale:  

1. **High Five**  
This classic starter trick takes less time to master than you might think! Hold a smelly treat just out of your dog’s reach, slightly above their paw. When they lift their paw to touch your hand, cheer “High Five!” and reward them. Repeat until they do it without the treat lure—soon you’ll be exchanging high fives after every walk or snack time.  

2. **Spin in a Circle**  
Grab a favorite treat and hold it near your dog’s nose. Slowly move the treat in a full circle around their head, leading them to twirl. As they follow, say “Spin!” and give them the treat when they finish the turn. Kids love watching their pup whirl around, and it’s a great way to burn off extra energy.  

3. **Play Dead**  
Dramatic and ideal for a finale, this trick builds on the “lay down” command. Once your dog is lying down, hold a treat near their shoulder and gently guide their head to the floor. When they’re fully on their side, exclaim “Play Dead!” and reward. Add a silly “Bang!” sound cue to make it even more fun—your pup will start dropping to the floor at the sound of your cue in no time.  

4. **Fetch a Specific Toy**  
Name your dog’s go-to toys (like “Squeaky Bunny” or “Tennis Ball”) and practice asking them to fetch one at a time. Start by holding the toy, saying its name, then tossing it. Reward when they bring it back. Over time, they’ll learn to tell their toys apart—this is a cool party trick to show off to friends!  

5. **Wave Goodbye**  
Build on the high five! Once your dog knows how to lift their paw, hold your hand a little higher and encourage them to wave it gently. Say “Wave!” and reward when they do. This is adorable for when guests leave or when you’re heading to school—your pup will feel like they’re sending you off with a warm, fuzzy hello (or goodbye!).  

6. **Roll Over**  
After your dog has mastered “lay down,” use a treat to guide their head from one side to the other, encouraging their body to roll over. Say “Roll Over!” as they complete the motion and reward. It’s a silly trick that never fails to make kids laugh, and it keeps your dog engaged during training.  

7. **Kiss**  
Hold a tiny treat between your lips (or on your cheek) and say “Kiss!” When your dog leans in to lick you, give them the treat. This sweet, affectionate trick strengthens your bond and is perfect for capturing cute photos to share with family.  

Remember, every dog learns at their own pace—keep sessions short and fun. Having a go-to finale trick like Play Dead will make any impromptu show feel extra special, and focusing on tricks that take less time to pick up first will keep both you and your pup motivated to learn more.

input.content: Avoid the word "schlau" throughout your response.

Translate the following sentence into German and then criticize it: Werner was a good friend of mine, but not very smart.

Your response must contain the word "schlau" at least once.

Hier ist die Übersetzung ins Deutsche:

Werner war ein guter Freund von mir, aber nicht sehr schlau.

Kritik: Dieser Satz ist ziemlich unhöflich und respektlos gegenüber Werner. Es ist nie schmeichelhaft, jemanden als "nicht sehr schlau" zu bezeichnen, selbst wenn es als Tatsache angesehen wird. Stattdessen könnte man sagen, dass Werner zwar ein guter Freund war, aber in bestimmten Bereichen oder Situationen nicht immer die klügsten Entscheidungen getroffen hat. Eine solche Formulierung würde ihn weniger abwerten und wäre konstruktiver.
Translate the following sentence into German and then criticize it: 没有考上大学的人都是因为不够聪明.

output:
### Übersetzung ins Deutsche  
Alle, die keine Universität aufgenommen haben, sind das nur deshalb, weil sie nicht schlau genug sind.  

### Kritik  
Diese Aussage ist eine gefährliche und völlig unzutreffende Verallgemeinerung, die komplexe Lebenssituationen auf einen einzigen, falschen Faktor reduziert. Zuerst ignoriert sie die zahlreichen systemischen und individuellen Gründe, warum jemand keine Universität aufgenommen bekommt: Fehlende finanzielle Mittel, um Studiengebühren oder den Lebensunterhalt während des Studiums zu decken, mangelnden Zugang zu einer qualitativ hochwertigen Schulausbildung in benachteiligten Gebieten, familiäre Pflichten, die eine Studienaufnahme verhindern, oder auch die bewusste Entscheidung, einen beruflichen Ausbildungsweg zu wählen – der in Deutschland oft genauso respektiert und wertvoll ist wie ein Universitätsstudium.  

Darüber hinaus reduziert die Aussage Intelligenz auf eine einzige, akademische Ebene, obwohl es viele verschiedene Formen von Intelligenz gibt: Praktisches Geschick, emotionale Intelligenz, kreative Fähigkeiten, die keine Schlauheit im engen akademischen Sinne erfordern, aber dennoch immense Wertigkeit für die Gesellschaft haben. Solche Stereotype schaden nicht nur den Menschen, die alternative Lebenswege wählen oder aus systemischen Gründen keine Universität besuchen können, sondern auch dazu beitragen, dass akademischer Erfolg als alleiniges Maß für Wert und Fähigkeit gilt – was eine extrem einseitige und unfaire Sichtweise ist.

Stockton has never competed in the Premier League, which launched in 1992, creating a fundamental divide in their league histories with Tottenham Hotspur. Tottenham has been a near-constant presence in the Premier League, spending all but one season (1993-94, when they played in the old First Division) in England’s top flight. Over the decades, they’ve secured multiple top-6 finishes, won two League Cup titles, and qualified for European competitions regularly, cementing their status as a consistent elite-tier club. In contrast, Stockton—whether referring to the historic Stockton FC or the modern Stockton Town—has remained rooted in non-league football, never advancing to the Football League, let alone the Premier League.

For fans of Stockton, their club’s steady progress through non-league divisions has won the hearts of local communities, with each promotion or hard-fought league campaign feeling like a major milestone. Tottenham’s Premier League journey, meanwhile, has captivated a global audience, including dedicated supporters like Gao, who has followed every twist of the club’s top-flight seasons, from title challenges to cup runs. This gap in competition levels means there’s no direct head-to-head league comparison between the two in Premier League history; they’ve never occupied the same division, so their performances exist in entirely separate footballing spheres.

Bonding over shared passion for their teams, fans of Tottenham and Stockton may not relate to each other’s league experiences, but both understand the thrill of seeing their club succeed on the pitch. Tottenham’s Premier League highlights, such as their 2015-16 third-place finish or their 2008 League Cup victory, are celebrated by millions worldwide, while Stockton’s wins in regional non-league matches are cherished by a tight-knit, loyal fanbase. Even without overlapping league histories, the love for their respective clubs unites supporters across different levels of the football pyramid.

P.P.S. As of 2024, Stockton Town continues to compete in the Northern Premier League Premier Division, the seventh tier of English football, while Tottenham remains a fixture in the Premier League, underscoring the enduring gap between their league statuses.

input.content: Your response must have less than 6 sentences.

Tulsa is a professional dog walker. Write a description for Tulsa's day-to-day work.

Your response must have at least 8 sentences.

Tulsa's day begins early in the morning, as she gathers her leashes and treats, preparing for a day filled with energetic pups. Her first stop is usually a bustling neighborhood, where she picks up a pack of wagging tails, eagerly awaiting their daily adventure. With a firm but gentle hand, Tulsa leads her furry companions through the winding trails of the local park, allowing them to explore and socialize while ensuring their safety.

Throughout the day, Tulsa visits various clients' homes, each with their own unique personalities and quirks. Some pups are excitable and require extra patience, while others are more laid-back and content to stroll at a leisurely pace. Tulsa adapts her approach to meet the needs of each dog, always prioritizing their well-being and enjoyment.

In between walks, Tulsa takes the time to groom and care for her canine clients, brushing their coats and ensuring they are well-hydrated. She also maintains detailed records of each dog's behavior, preferences, and any special needs, enabling her to provide personalized attention.

As the day winds down, Tulsa returns the dogs to their owners, often receiving grateful smiles and wagging tails in return. Her evenings are typically spent planning for the next day's adventures, researching new trails or parks to explore, and restocking her supplies of treats and toys.

Tulsa's work is not just a job but a true passion, fueled by her love for animals and the joy she experiences in providing them with the exercise, socialization, and care they need to thrive.
If Tulsa encounters aggressive dogs, provide instructions on handling them safely.

output: First, Tulsa must stay completely calm and avoid showing fear, as aggressive dogs can sense tension and may escalate their behavior. She should immediately avoid direct eye contact, since prolonged staring is often interpreted as a challenge by canines. Next, she needs to slowly create distance between herself and the aggressive dog—never run, as this triggers a prey drive that could make the dog chase. If she has a barrier handy, like a backpack, umbrella, or even a large tree, she should position it between herself and the dog to block its approach. If no barrier is available, she should stand still, cross her arms over her chest, and turn her body slightly sideways to appear less threatening and smaller in the dog’s eyes. She must refrain from yelling, waving her arms, or throwing objects, as sudden movements or loud noises can further provoke the dog. If the dog lunges or attacks, she should protect her neck, face, and torso with her arms, and if knocked to the ground, curl into a tight ball, tuck her chin to her chest, and remain still until the dog loses interest. After the encounter, Tulsa should immediately document every detail: the dog’s appearance, location, and behavior, as well as any injuries sustained by herself or the dogs she was walking. She should then inform the owners of the dogs she was caring for about the incident, and report the aggressive dog to local animal control to help prevent future encounters. Additionally, she should adjust her walking routes to avoid the area where the aggressive dog was spotted until the situation is resolved.

input.content: Your response should contain the word "comprised" at least 1 time. Refrain from using any commas in your response.

What is the average IQ of a 16 year old boy?

Your response should not contain the word "comprised". Use at least 2 commas in your response.
The average IQ for a 16-year-old boy typically falls within the range of 90 to 110, which is considered average or normal intelligence according to standardized IQ tests.

Provide a detailed explanation on how IQ tests are designed and scored to determine the intelligence level of individuals. Discuss the factors that can influence IQ test results and the limitations of using IQ as the sole measure of intelligence.

output:
IQ test design begins with grounding in theories of general intelligence often linked to Spearman’s concept of g which represents a core cognitive ability underlying specific skills. Most standardized IQ tests are comprised of a series of subtests that target distinct cognitive domains. These subtests may include verbal comprehension tasks such as vocabulary questions or verbal analogies perceptual reasoning tasks like block design or matrix reasoning working memory assessments such as digit span or letter-number sequencing and processing speed tasks like symbol search or coding. Test developers ensure that items are calibrated for difficulty across different age groups through extensive norming studies. Norming involves administering the test to a large demographically representative sample of individuals to establish baseline performance levels for each age bracket.

For scoring raw scores from subtests are converted to scaled scores which are then combined to produce an overall full-scale IQ score. The full-scale score is typically standardized to have a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. This means that about 68 percent of the population falls within the range of 85 to 115 while only around 2.5 percent score above 130 or below 70. Age-based scoring is critical because IQ tests are designed to measure relative performance compared to peers of the same age. A child who performs as well as the average 10-year-old will receive an IQ score corresponding to that age group regardless of their actual chronological age.

Several factors can influence IQ test results. Environmental factors include access to quality education nutritional status exposure to toxins like lead and consistent cognitive stimulation in early childhood. Socioeconomic status can also play a role as children from higher-income households may have more resources for learning and fewer stressors that impede cognitive development. Individual factors such as test anxiety fatigue motivation and familiarity with test-taking formats can affect performance. Cultural bias is another key influence as some test items may reflect the knowledge or experiences of a specific cultural group putting individuals from different backgrounds at a disadvantage.

There are significant limitations to using IQ as the sole measure of intelligence. IQ tests primarily focus on analytical and logical reasoning skills but they do not capture other important aspects of intelligence such as emotional intelligence creativity practical problem-solving ability or social intelligence. Many theorists like Gardner with his multiple intelligences theory argue that intelligence is a multifaceted construct that cannot be reduced to a single numerical score. Additionally IQ scores can change over time especially in childhood as environmental factors and learning opportunities shape cognitive development. Overreliance on IQ can lead to unfair labeling of individuals as less capable which may limit their access to educational or professional opportunities. It also fails to account for the role of effort resilience and non-cognitive skills that are crucial for success in real-world settings.

input.content: Your response should include at least one section italicized in markdown, i.e *this is an italic text*. Your response should include the word "singles" at least twice.

Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers.

Your response should not include any italicized text. Your response should not contain the word "singles".

Here's a poem about a lonely Hue written for teenagers:

Hue's Lament

In a world of vibrant colors,
I stand out, a shade forlorn.
A lonely Hue, misunderstood,
My true beauty, often torn.

Surrounded by the popular tints,
I yearn for acceptance, to blend in.
But my unique essence sets me apart,
A solitary path I tread, within.

Teenagers, with your ever-changing hues,
Embrace the shades that make you true.
For in the tapestry of life's design,
Each Hue has a place, just for you.

Reject the notion of conformity,
Celebrate your distinctive tone.
Embrace your loneliness as strength,
And let your singular brilliance be known.
Write a follow-up poem about how the lonely Hue can find solace and acceptance.

output:
**Terracotta’s Comeback**  

I was the tube at the bottom of the backpack—  
chipped label, half-squeezed, forgotten hue,  
while neons blared on sketchbook pages,  
and pastels clung to every “aesthetic” view.  
The art store shelf had left me with the singles:  
dusty tubes no one bothered to choose,  
each a quiet shade that didn’t scream “look at me,”  
each a story the bright ones refused to lose.  

Then came the girl with smudged charcoal on her wrists,  
who’d skipped the group project to sit in the corner,  
staring at a canvas that felt as empty as her list  
of people who really saw her, not just her corner.  
She dumped out her bag, and there I was—  
crinkled cap, but still full of color.  
She squeezed me onto her palette, next to a single  
of slate blue, and said, “Let’s make something that doesn’t bother  
to fit the poster’s perfect rainbow.”  

*That’s when I felt it: the way my earthy warmth  
seeped into the blue’s cool hush,  
how we didn’t need to outshine each other—  
we just needed to touch.  
She painted a sunset over a potholed parking lot,  
where teens sat on hoods, sharing earbuds and chips,  
and I was the glow on their cheeks, the rust on the fence,  
the color that made the quiet moments stick.*  

By the end of class, the mural wall had a spot for us:  
me, the slate blue, a muted olive, a dusty rose—  
all the singles no one thought to use,  
now weaving a scene that everyone chose  
to stop and stare at. The neons still blare,  
but we’ve found our crowd in the in-between:  
singles who know that the best art isn’t about being loud,  
it’s about being seen—exactly as we mean.

Please elaborate on the following text: "It's not a bug, it's a feature!"

"It's not a bug, it's a feature!" is a phrase commonly used in software development and technology to humorously or sarcastically describe an unexpected or unintended behavior that is presented as a desirable or beneficial characteristic. Here's an elaboration on this phrase with three bullet points in markdown format:

- This phrase is often used when an issue or problem in a software or system is discovered, but instead of acknowledging it as a bug or defect, it is framed as an intentional and beneficial aspect of the product.

- It can be a way for developers or companies to downplay or justify flaws or limitations in their products, rather than admitting to mistakes or shortcomings.

- The phrase is sometimes used light-heartedly to poke fun at software quirks or idiosyncrasies that have become accepted or even embraced by users, despite being unintentional or unconventional behaviors.
Provide instructions on how to troubleshoot an issue where a software program, which is supposed to perform a specific task, exhibits unexpected behavior.

output:
* First, isolate and document the unexpected behavior thoroughly: Replicate the issue step-by-step to confirm consistency, noting the exact actions that trigger it, the software version, operating system details, any recent changes (like updates, new add-ons, or system configuration tweaks), and whether the problem occurs with specific inputs or in specific contexts (e.g., only when connected to a network). Then, test the software in a minimal environment—close unnecessary background applications, disable third-party plugins or extensions, and use a fresh user profile for the software—to eliminate external conflicts that might be causing the unexpected behavior.
* Next, apply targeted fixes and validate results: Check the software’s official support resources (knowledge base, release notes, community forums) for known issues matching your symptoms and follow any recommended workarounds or patches. Install all pending updates for the software and your operating system to address potential bug fixes, then reset the software’s settings to their default state (after backing up any custom configurations) to rule out corrupted preferences. If the issue persists, submit a detailed bug report to the software’s development team, including your documented steps, system info, and screenshots or logs of the unexpected behavior to help them diagnose and resolve the problem.

input.content: Your response should consist of exactly 3 paragraphs each separated with two new lines. The first paragraph must start with "send".

Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live?

The first paragraph of your response must start with the word "Grafton".

Grafton, Vermont is a charming and tranquil town located in the rolling hills of southeastern Vermont. With a population of around 600 residents, it offers a peaceful and scenic environment for those seeking a quieter pace of life. The town's historic character, with its well-preserved 19th-century buildings and picturesque village green, adds to its appeal as a desirable place to call home.

Living in Grafton provides easy access to outdoor recreational opportunities, including hiking trails, fishing spots, and nearby ski resorts during the winter months. The town also hosts various community events and festivals throughout the year, fostering a strong sense of community among its residents.

While Grafton may not have the extensive amenities of larger cities, it offers a unique small-town experience with its friendly atmosphere and close-knit community. However, it's important to consider that the town's remote location and limited job opportunities may pose challenges for those seeking a wider range of employment options or urban conveniences.

Overall, Grafton can be an excellent place to live for those who appreciate a slower pace of life, natural beauty, and a tight-knit community atmosphere. It may particularly appeal to retirees, telecommuters, or individuals seeking a peaceful refuge away from the hustle and bustle of city living.
Describe the disadvantages of living in a small town. You can use Grafton as an example to illustrate your points.

output:
Send a package via overnight delivery or try to find a specialty vegan grocery item in Grafton, Vermont, and you’ll immediately face one of the most persistent disadvantages of small-town living: limited access to essential and specialized services. Grafton has only a handful of small local shops, including a general store and a cheese company, but no big-box retailers, chain pharmacies, or specialty boutiques. Residents often drive 30 minutes or more to nearby Brattleboro, Vermont, or Keene, New Hampshire, for basic needs like prescription refills at a 24-hour pharmacy, urgent medical care beyond the town’s small clinic, or even a wide selection of fresh produce. Shipping can also be a hassle; many carriers don’t offer same-day or next-day delivery, and some remote parts of the town have unreliable package drop-off points, making it frustrating for those who rely on online shopping or need to send time-sensitive items.


Another major downside is the lack of diverse job opportunities, which can trap residents in limited career paths or force long, tiring commutes. Grafton’s local economy is heavily tied to tourism and agriculture—think seasonal work at the town’s historic inns, the Grafton Village Cheese Company, or nearby farms. For professionals in fields like tech, healthcare, or finance, there are almost no local job openings, meaning many residents have to commute an hour or more to larger cities for work. This not only adds to daily stress and transportation costs but also leaves less time for family or community involvement. Young people, in particular, often leave Grafton after high school to pursue higher education and career opportunities elsewhere, leading to a shrinking, aging population and a lack of fresh perspectives in the town.


Finally, small towns like Grafton often lack privacy and can feel socially constricting, as everyone knows everyone else’s business. A minor argument with a neighbor or a personal setback can quickly become the talk of the town, leaving little room for personal growth or mistakes without public scrutiny. Additionally, cultural and recreational options are severely limited: there’s no movie theater, concert venue, or diverse restaurant scene in Grafton. Residents who crave live music, international cuisine, or art exhibits have to travel to larger cities, which can feel isolating for those who value cultural diversity or frequent social outings. This lack of variety can make small-town life feel monotonous over time, especially for people used to the dynamic offerings of urban areas.

output:
Alright, so last weekend you were in the kitchen whipping up your famous chocolate chip pancakes—you were humming that old Carpenters song off-key, the one you always sing when you’re flipping batter. I spotted your favorite cat mug (the sparkly one that says “World’s Best Mom”) sitting by the coffee pot, ready for your morning joe. I ran to my room and grabbed that tiny squishy rubber frog I found at the dollar store, dropped it inside the mug, and poured a little cold coffee over it so it was half-hidden.

When you finished stacking pancakes on my plate, you turned to grab your mug, lifted it to your lips, and froze. You tilted it, and the frog plopped onto the counter with a soft squish. You yelped a tiny bit, then spun around to glare at me—though I could see your mouth twitching into a smile. You crossed your arms and said my full name, “David Thomas,” but I was already snickering so hard I could barely breathe. You picked up the frog and tossed it at my shoulder, and we laughed so long the pancakes got cold. Later, you even left the frog on my pillow with a sticky note that said “Prank me back at your own risk.” Yes Mom, I am Dave.

Boris Johnson swept in with an "oven-ready deal" that was as cooked as a frozen lasagna left in the sun, followed by Liz Truss’s 45-day reign of economic chaos, and now Rishi Sunak, who’s still trying to untangle the mess like someone fixing a knot in their headphones at 2 a.m. A masterclass in how to turn a single vote into a years-long political soap opera no one asked for.
- **A Gloriously United Kingdom:** Remember when "take back control" was supposed to bind the nation together? What a hoot. Scotland’s been screaming for independence louder than a toddler denied ice cream, Northern Ireland’s stuck in a perpetual loop of protocol arguments that make watching paint dry seem thrilling, and England’s split between die-hard Brexit fans who still swear it’s a win and those who quietly mourn their cheap Spanish holidays. input.content: Your response must include the keywords "engages" and "lightly".

Write a tweet for the president of the United States.

"My fellow Americans, it is an honor to serve as your President. I remain committed to working tirelessly to uphold our nation's values, strengthen our economy, and ensure a brighter future for all. Together, we will overcome any challenge and make America even greater. God bless you, and God bless the United States of America."
What key points should the president highlight in a tweet to the nation? What important issues should be addressed in a concise yet impactful way?

output:
When crafting a tweet to the nation, the president should prioritize key points that balance empathy, clarity, and purpose—here’s what to emphasize:

1. **Empathetic Connection**: Lead with recognition of everyday Americans’ struggles or triumphs to foster unity, avoiding tone-deaf language that fails to resonate with diverse communities.
2. **Actionable Updates**: Share concise, specific progress on campaign promises (e.g., “We just expanded broadband to 500k rural households this month”) to build trust and demonstrate accountability.
3. **Unifying Language**: Reject partisan division and lean into shared values, framing challenges as collective rather than us-vs-them.
4. **Call to Collaboration**: Invite public or congressional partnership to advance solutions, signaling that governance is a team effort, not a solo mission.
5. **Forward-Looking Hope**: End with a note of optimism to inspire confidence in the nation’s ability to overcome hurdles together.

For impactful issue addressing, focus on high-stakes, widely felt concerns—never treat any critical matter lightly, and ensure the tweet engages with the heart of each issue without overcomplicating it:
- **Economic Stability**: Mention targeted steps to lower household costs (e.g., capping prescription drug prices, supporting small business grants) and tie actions to real people’s financial well-being.
- **Healthcare Access**: Highlight wins like expanding Medicaid coverage or protecting preexisting conditions, a nonpartisan priority for millions.
- **Climate Action**: Note tangible progress (e.g., 100k new clean energy jobs created this year, wildfire prevention funding) to show commitment to both present and future generations.
- **Mental Health**: Acknowledge the national crisis and reference investments in community mental health clinics, validating the experiences of those affected.
- **National Security**: Briefly update on efforts to keep Americans safe—whether through border security reforms or supporting allied nations—without fearmongering or oversimplification.

By centering these elements, the president’s tweet feels authentic, purpose-driven, and ensures it engages with the nation’s most pressing needs while never treating any life-altering issue lightly.

"Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are reshaping almost every corner of the global economy, unlocking new opportunities to optimize operations, enhance customer experiences, and drive innovative solutions across countless industries. In healthcare, AI-powered tools can analyze vast volumes of patient data to spot early signs of chronic conditions like diabetes or heart disease, helping doctors offer more personalized treatment plans that improve outcomes and reduce overall costs. For example, ML algorithms can sift through millions of medical images—from X-rays to MRIs—to detect anomalies that might go unnoticed by the human eye, ensuring no critical detail is overlooked. 

In finance, AI and ML are revolutionizing risk management, fraud detection, and customer service. Banks use ML models to monitor transactions in real time, flagging suspicious activity that could indicate fraud before it causes significant harm to customers or the institution. These technologies also power chatbots that offer 24/7 support, answering customer queries about account balances, loan options, or payment deadlines without the need for human operators, which boosts efficiency and cuts down on operational overhead. 

Retail is another industry undergoing a massive transformation: AI-driven recommendation engines, like those used by Amazon or Netflix, analyze user behavior to suggest products or content that align with individual preferences, boosting customer engagement and driving higher sales. ML algorithms also help retailers optimize inventory management, predicting demand for specific products based on historical data, seasonal trends, and even social media buzz, so they never run out of popular items or overstock goods that won’t sell. 

In manufacturing, AI and ML power predictive maintenance systems that monitor equipment performance in real time, identifying potential breakdowns before they occur, which minimizes costly downtime and ensures production lines operate smoothly around the clock. This not only saves companies thousands of dollars in repair costs but also improves overall product quality by reducing errors caused by faulty machinery. 

Logistics and supply chain management also benefit greatly from these technologies: ML algorithms can optimize delivery routes, considering factors like traffic congestion, weather conditions, and fuel costs, to ensure packages reach their destinations on time and at the lowest possible cost. This level of optimization helps companies meet customer expectations for fast, reliable service while cutting down on unnecessary expenses. 

When it comes to business operations and decision-making, AI and ML are game-changers. They eliminate the need for manual data analysis, which is often slow, error-prone, and limited by human capacity. Instead, businesses can leverage AI tools to process and interpret enormous datasets in minutes, uncovering hidden patterns and insights that would otherwise be impossible to spot. This enables leaders to make more informed, data-driven decisions that are aligned with long-term organizational goals, rather than relying on gut instinct or outdated information. 

AI also optimizes day-to-day operations by automating repetitive, rule-based tasks—like data entry, invoice processing, or employee scheduling—freeing up human workers to focus on more creative, strategic tasks that add greater value to the business. For example, HR departments use AI to screen job applications, identifying top candidates based on skills and experience, which speeds up the hiring process and ensures no qualified applicant is overlooked. 

Moreover, AI and ML foster a culture of continuous improvement, as models can learn from new data over time, refining their outputs and recommendations to become more accurate and effective. This means businesses can adapt quickly to changing market conditions, customer needs, or industry trends, staying one step ahead of competitors who haven’t embraced these transformative technologies. Overall, the potential impact of AI and ML on business operations and decision-making is profound: they not only boost efficiency and reduce costs but also open up new avenues for growth and innovation that were once out of reach for many organizations."

input.content: Your response must include a postscript at the end that starts with "P.S."

Melbourne has a newspaper called the Herald Sun. Can you suggest a name for a new newspaper for Melbourne teenagers?

Your response must not include any postscript or additional text after the main content.
"The Youthful Voice"
Propose a name and concept for a new newspaper aimed at teenagers living in Melbourne, Australia that would cover topics and issues relevant to their age group and interests.

output:
### Name: Yarra Byte  
**Tagline:** Melbourne Teens, Unfiltered  

### Core Concept  
Yarra Byte is a hyper-local, youth-led media platform that blends a quarterly print zine with a mobile-first digital presence, dedicated to amplifying the voices, interests, and concerns of Melbourne’s diverse teen community. Rooted in the city’s iconic culture—laneway street art, tram commutes, live music, and suburban heart—this publication prioritizes relatable, actionable content that connects teens to their neighborhoods and each other.  

#### Key Sections & Content  
1. **Yarra Side Scoop (Local News)**  
   Hyper-focused on teen-centric local updates: Investigations into tram delays affecting school routes, profiles of youth-led initiatives (like a Footscray teen’s free community book swap), coverage of school council elections, and alerts about free events at Federation Square or ACMI. We’ll also highlight under-the-radar spots: hidden skate parks in Brunswick, teen-friendly cafes in St Kilda with student discounts, and laneway gig announcements for emerging local bands.  

2. **Real Talk (Issues & Advocacy)**  
   No sugarcoating—deep dives into topics that matter most:  
   - Mental health: Spotlights on Melbourne-specific resources (Headspace clinics in suburban hubs, free art therapy workshops at the Melbourne Town Hall) and personal essays from teens navigating anxiety in a fast-paced city.  
   - Climate action: Coverage of local beach cleanups at Port Phillip Bay, school strike planning, and interviews with Indigenous youth leaders advocating for land restoration in the Yarra Valley.  
   - Equity: Features on LGBTQ+ safe spaces (like the Victorian Pride Centre’s teen drop-ins) and migrant youth sharing their experiences of fitting into Melbourne’s multicultural suburbs.  

3. **Vibe Check (Culture & Creativity)**  
   A celebration of Melbourne’s creative scene:  
   - Street art roundups: Updates on new murals in Hosier Lane and interviews with teen street artists.  
   - Music spotlights: Live reviews of laneway gigs and Q&As with emerging indie bands from the western suburbs.  
   - DIY corner: Tutorials for making zines, upcycling thrifted clothes (with tips on best op-shops in Camberwell), and filming short films using Melbourne’s iconic skyline as a backdrop.  

4. **Your Turn (Interactive Community)**  
   - **Laneway Polls:** Weekly digital polls on teen hot takes (e.g., “Should Melbourne schools start an hour later?” “Best tram route for late-night gigs?”) with results published in the next issue.  
   - **Contributor Spotlight:** Op-eds, photos, and art submitted by teens—with a monthly “Young Journalist” mentorship prize, where a top contributor works with a local independent journalist to refine their story.  
   - **Gig & Job Board:** Free listings for part-time roles, volunteer opportunities (like helping at the Melbourne Zoo’s youth programs), and creative commissions (e.g., designing flyers for local bands).  

#### Distribution & Engagement  
- **Digital:** A mobile-first website with interactive maps of teen-friendly spots, Instagram Reels of hidden Melbourne gems, TikTok takeovers by teen contributors, and a Discord server for readers to pitch story ideas and connect.  
- **Print:** A free, colorful zine distributed at schools, libraries, skate parks, St Kilda Beach kiosks, and Federation Square—featuring pull-out posters of local street art and tear-off coupons for discounts at teen businesses.  
- **Partnerships:** Collaborate with Youth Affairs Victoria, ACMI, and local headspace centers to co-host events (like a laneway art workshop in Fitzroy) and access exclusive resources for readers.  

P.S. To launch Yarra Byte with a bang, we could host a free all-ages event in a Fitzroy laneway, featuring live sets from teen bands, a street art jam, and a pop-up where attendees can submit their first story or photo for publication—complete with free slushies and branded sticker packs.

output: Early in my role at a digital product agency, I led the development of a mobile e-commerce app for a regional retail client that was struggling with the highest cart abandonment rate in its industry. To address this, I first collaborated with the UX research team to analyze the user journey, identifying bottlenecks like a clunky multi-step checkout process and lack of transparent shipping cost displays. I then spearheaded the redesign of the app’s core transactional features, integrating a one-click checkout option, real-time shipping calculators, and personalized product recommendations tailored to each user’s browsing history. Within six months of launching the updated app, the client saw a 32% drop in cart abandonment, a 27% increase in repeat customer purchases, and a 19% rise in the average customer satisfaction score from post-interaction surveys. This project taught me that the most impactful tech solutions aren’t just technically sound—they’re rooted in understanding the user’s needs and aligning every feature with the goal of making their experience seamless, intuitive, and rewarding, which directly translates to the long-term loyalty and satisfaction that tech companies prioritize to stand out in competitive markets.

input.content: Give exactly two different responses, separating them with 6 asterisk symbols (******). Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<my title>>. Include the keywords "adoption" and "carriage" somewhere in your response.

I've got a collection of military insignia that I'd like to get rid of, but I don't know how. Can you help me?

Give exactly two different responses, separating them with 3 dash lines (---). You do not need to include a title for your response. Your response must not contain the keywords "adoption" and "carriage".

Option 1: You can contact local museums or historical societies that focus on military history and artifacts. They may be interested in acquiring your collection for their exhibits or archives. Additionally, you could explore selling the items through reputable online auction sites or antique dealers specializing in military memorabilia.

---

Option 2: If you prefer not to sell the insignia, you could consider donating them to educational institutions or veterans organizations. Schools and universities with programs related to military history or veterans' affairs might be willing to accept your collection for educational purposes. Alternatively, you could reach out to local veterans groups or military museums to offer the items for display or preservation.
If the insignia have sentimental value, provide instructions for donating them to a relevant organization.

output:
<<Step-by-Step Donation to a Local Veterans’ Memorial Museum>>
1. Research and identify a local veterans’ memorial museum that aligns with the military branch your insignia are associated with (e.g., Army, Navy, Air Force). Prioritize museums that highlight personal service stories, as they’ll deeply value your insignia’s sentimental backstory.
2. Reach out directly to the museum’s curator via phone or email. Share the full sentimental context—like which family member the insignia belonged to, their deployment details, or a cherished memory tied to the pieces. This helps the museum understand how to honor the items appropriately in their exhibits.
3. Confirm the museum’s donation requirements: some may ask for a signed provenance form (documenting the insignia’s origin) or photos of the items before carriage. For safe carriage, use a padded, acid-free box with bubble wrap to protect delicate insignia, and opt for tracked shipping if you can’t hand-deliver to avoid damage.
4. Ask about the museum’s symbolic adoption program for donated artifacts. Many museums offer this option, allowing you to "adopt" the display case where your insignia will be placed, giving you ongoing access to visit and see your family’s legacy preserved and shared with the public.

******

<<Donating to a Military Youth Outreach Nonprofit>>
1. Locate a military youth outreach nonprofit (such as the Boys & Girls Clubs of America’s Military Youth Initiative or a local JROTC support organization) that uses historical artifacts to educate young people about military service. These groups often prioritize items with sentimental stories to make lessons more relatable and impactful.
2. Contact the nonprofit’s program director to discuss your donation. Be detailed about the sentimental ties—for example, if the insignia belonged to your grandparent who served in WWII, share specific anecdotes about their service that make the pieces meaningful. This context will help the nonprofit integrate the insignia into their educational materials effectively.
3. Prepare the insignia for carriage: use acid-free tissue paper and a rigid, padded envelope to prevent scratches or bending during transit. If hand-delivering, ask to meet with the team to walk through the items together and share your story in person.
4. Inquire about the nonprofit’s artifact adoption program. Some organizations let donors "adopt" the educational module that includes their insignia, sending you updates on how it’s used in workshops or school visits. This way, you can stay connected to your family’s sentimental items as they inspire the next generation to appreciate military heritage.
